PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and relates to economic growth. I remind the Minister that yesterday morning he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I mean, we gave growth figures in the Budget forecasts. I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those now. . .

Within a few hours he had put out a press release headed, `Budget forecasts will be met, says Button'. I ask the Minister: what caused him to revise his statement so soon after? Did it have anything to do with his discussions in the meantime with Treasurer Dawkins, or was it, as one commentator has said, `In the morning we saw Honest John and in the afternoon Political John'?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very surprised that Senator Hill should ask me this question today. It is unduly astute of him. I suppose the important thing is that my view is the Budget forecast will be met.
—Why didn't you say that in the morning?

—If Senator Hill does not mind, I will answer the question. The Budget forecast is for growth to accelerate through the year to provide average growth of 3 per cent in 1992-93 compared with 1991-92. The important point is that the economy is not yet growing at 3 per cent. I believe it will reach that figure. The only figures we have to rely on at the moment are those from the June quarter where the annualised growth rate was 2 1/2 per cent. There are no available official figures we can rely on at this time; no official figures are available. I believe the forecast will be met and I believed that as at yesterday morning.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill asked what made me change my mind—as he put it—in the period between the Channel 9 interview and later in the day when I put out a press release. Immediately after the Channel 9 interview had concluded, I realised that I had put what I said very badly—
Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, that is true. I then took steps to put out a press release which reflected my view—and the view which I have put in the Senate on a number of occasions—that the Budget forecasts were conservative. Indeed, if Senator Hill examines the Channel 9 interview in detail, he will see that, on the basis of my discussions with business and so on, I put that very view: businesses were reporting increased activity, increased sales and some increase in profits—and that is consistent with the view.
—Why did you have that doubt yesterday morning?

—Senator Alston interjects. The point is, as I have said on a number of occasions: the growth rates are conservative. I personally was expecting higher growth rates earlier in the financial year than we may be achieving; I do not know—we do not know until we get the official figures. But, in so far as I was disappointed about that—and looking at it at the present time—we are not achieving a 3 per cent growth rate at the present time. Later in the year, as the growth rates are announced quarter by quarter, I believe that we will achieve that result, and the through-the-year result will be 3 per cent in accordance with the Budget forecast.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister of that part of my question in which I asked him whether his change of view had anything to do with his discussions in the meantime with Treasurer Dawkins. But, arising out of his answer, I also ask: although he says no official figures are available, has the Government in fact received any advice since the Budget suggesting that perhaps its growth forecast was overoptimistic? Was the Minister taking into account any such advice in his statement on the Channel 9 program?
—I will deal with the second part of the question first: the Government has received no official advice that its growth forecasts in the Budget are not on target.
—Semi-official?

—Indeed, as far as one can refer to semi-official advice, the Governor of the Reserve Bank said, last week I think it was, that in his view those targets would be met—he said that in one way or another. On the first part of the question, I had a discussion with Treasurer Dawkins about this matter yesterday, on two occasions. I have already answered this part of the question because, as I said to Senator Hill in the earlier part, when I left Channel 9 I recognised that I had expressed that badly and I took steps to put out a press release before I had any discussions with Mr Dawkins.

—My question relates to interest rates on credit cards. I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs whether he is aware of reports in the media suggesting that these rates could fall in the near future. Given the Minister's previous calls in the Senate for banks to reduce their credit card rates, would he outline whether the Government still regards such a fall as desirable?

—I do notice that some of the banks are belatedly responding to marketplace realities and are in fact signalling that they will reduce interest rates either today or over the next several days. But, really, that is no cause for great applause, and I am quite sure that the Australian people will not be particularly thanking the banks because they are simply passing on to credit card holders the benefit of the fact that the banks have had access to borrowing cheaper money now for many months.

PARA.TAB: In fact, as the Minister for Consumer Affairs over the past several months, before I lost that particular portfolio, I had been working assiduously with the State consumer affairs Ministers to try to bring the banks—the so-called apostles of the marketplace—to pass on to consumers the benefits of the cheaper money they have been able to borrow.

We have always been met, of course, by the claim by the banks that the credit card business is unprofitable, which raises the question of why they stay in that particular marketplace offering that product year after year.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good question.

—I agree with Senator Panizza, it is a very good question. It will be very interesting to see what the Prices Surveillance Authority has to say about that matter, particularly as the banks never mention the merchant fees charged to the restaurateurs, the retailers and the hotel and motel operators who all pay a transaction fee whenever one of these deals is transacted.

PARA.TAB: So it will be most interesting to see how profitable they have been. Nevertheless, there is an argument that, on the grounds of equity, if the banks were permitted to levy a modest annual administrative fee on credit card holders, it would definitely enable them to reduce interest rates substantially.

Indeed, consumer affairs Ministers have said that, if State legislation is to be altered to enable a modest annual fee to be charged, there must be total, complete, utter offsetting of that annual fee with a commensurate substantial decrease in interest rates—and of course there would have to be cast iron guarantees that it would not last only for a few weeks but would be extended into the future. These matters are for State legislation, but it will be most interesting to see the Prices Surveillance Authority report in relation to credit card fees, transactions and annual fees possibility.

But I reiterate that in return for a modest annual administrative fee there would have to be most substantial cuts in interest rates absolutely and utterly offsetting that annual fee. If that occurred, I think that then at last Australian consumers of credit—and we all use these cards; we all live in a credit debt ridden society—those of us who use these cards, may get the benefit at last of a true reduction in interest rates, very belated but in that case welcome.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the Minister of the Treasurer's statement yesterday that Senator Button has `become famous over the years' for statements which are `entirely his own' and not the Government's, and the Treasurer's acknowledgment in the House of Representatives just a few minutes ago that Senator Button has acknowledged that he got it wrong yesterday. However, as we know in the Senate, many of these famous statements of Senator Button's have proven to be true; for example, his statement in May 1991 that:

QUESTION.PARA: I would not with any confidence say that unemployment in this country could not reach . . . 10 per cent.

Given his previous record of delivering honest views ahead of his colleagues, I ask Senator Button: why should we believe the Prime Minister or the Treasurer rather than himself that he is not confident the economy will achieve the Budget growth forecast?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already, in part, answered that question in answer to Senator Hill. But what I said on the Channel 9 program yesterday was that I did not believe or I was not absolutely confident that we will attain a 3 per cent growth rate now, and I am not confident that we will obtain a 3 per cent growth rate now, at the present time. But through the year—
—Oh, that is not what you said.

—I just quoted the words I said. But through the year, over the course of the year, we will attain that target—and that is what I am confident about. I have said that in the Senate before, I said it yesterday in the course of my press release, and everything I said in the Channel 9 program was consistent with that view. So throughout the Channel 9 interview yesterday, I was identifying myself with the position which was put by the Prime Minister last week.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As I understood Senator Button in his answer, he said that he had said and he still says that he is not confident now, at the present time, that we will achieve 3 per cent growth in 1992-93. I ask: when does he think that he may feel confident about this?
—I think Senator Short ought to listen to the answer.
—You read the Hansard report.
—I have said on three occasions in the Senate today already that I believe we will achieve the Budget target, which is 3 per cent through the year 1992-93.
—Why are you not confident of that now?

—As I said earlier in answer to a question, the only official figures we have to rely on are showing a 2 1/2 per cent growth rate in the economy at the present time, not 3 per cent as I had hoped at the present time—2 1/2 per cent.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I ask: is the Minister aware of proposals being promoted by the Victorian Government to abolish parliamentary by-elections as a cost-saving measure? Does this recommend itself to the Federal Government as sufficient to cause a policy change at a national level in similar circumstances, or is the response of the Federal Government to reject such a notion out of hand?

—I have seen reports emanating from the week-long Kennett Government, and basically the reports are for a proposal which would scrap by-elections when a government has at least a three-seat majority and the incumbent party would fill any such vacancies.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Government rejects those proposals out of hand and we do so for a number of good reasons. In doing so, we are in good company. We are part of a broad rejection of this policy initiative in a coalition which includes the Victorian Opposition, the Victorian Council of Civil Liberties, I am pleased to see the Australian Democrats, Phil Cleary and, of course, Bruce Ruxton. The strange unity ticket in support of it seems to be the Kennett Government and the former Democrat leader, Don Chipp.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those are hardly parties.
—At least we are a party, unlike the Liberals in Queensland, Senator Macdonald. You can't even get 10 seats there.

—Senator Ray makes a pertinent point. The only unity ticket in support of the proposal seems to encompass the Kennett Government and the former Democrat leader, Don Chipp, who would support it if factions were not involved in selecting the person to take over those seats. This is an absurd approach by former Senator Don Chipp.

PARA.TAB: We reject the proposal because it is undemocratic. It represents an absurdist approach to economic rationalism. We are told it is put up because it will save money. We say quite simply that one cannot put a price on democracy. It is undemocratic because it has come up at a time some seven or eight days after an election during which this particular issue was not put up by the then Opposition. It would be an abuse of power to proceed.

It is also undemocratic if one were to look at the concept of parliamentary democracy. At the core of that concept is the notion of elected representation. One wonders what the High Court would do with this proposal because quite basic to its most recent decision was the protection of the application of political participation. An approach which jointly covers section 106 of the Constitution and that most recent decision raises some very serious questions about the constitutionality of any such proposal.

We also reject it because it is undemocratic in that it embraces a concept of representation which is one that we reject totally. Mr Storey, who has floated this proposal on behalf of the Kennett Government, says that we should ask the people whether they really want the right to vote in a by-election which has no meaning. That is based on a concept that we reject. It is important to people to know who represents them, to have a choice in that selection and a choice in who acts for them during terms of government. We do not see members of parliament as voting fodder, as do Mr Storey and Mr Kennett.

The other problem we have with it is that it is unworkable. If it is based on the concept, presumably, that a majority of three is needed to cover the number of vacancies, who is to know how many vacancies will occur during the course of government? Mr President, the Senate is not a good example. According to the Constitution under which the Senate voting system is provided, direct representation is provided for the lower House, the House in which parliaments are elected and selected. That is precisely why there needs to be a direct approach to filling vacancies in the lower Houses. We reject the proposal because, firstly, it is undemocratic; secondly, it is probably unworkable; and, thirdly, it is possibly unconstitutional.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the reported comments of the ALP's National Secretary, Mr Bob Hogg, in Saturday's Weekend Australian in which he raised the possibility that Labor in opposition would vote in favour of a goods and services tax. Will the Minister confirm that the Keating Government is opposed to a goods and services tax and has told the voting public of its opposition loudly and often in the run up to the election? Secondly, is there any prospect that Labor's opposition to a GST will evaporate after the election?

—I did not see the comments attributed to Mr Hogg on this issue. Senator Coulter has asked for confirmation of the fact that the Labor Party is opposed to a goods and services tax. That is so, and that will remain the position.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. I note the very enlightened comments expressed recently by the Minister at a conference on juvenile justice and sentencing options. What practical measures are Federal and State Ministers considering to deal more effectively with young offenders?

—Some weeks ago in Adelaide a conference was held under the auspices of the Institute of Criminology at which a gathering of national and international experts addressed the question of juvenile justice, which is of concern to us all. I think all honourable senators would agree that every step ought to be taken to deal with those who engage in anti-social behaviour, particularly if it is violent behaviour, in a way which is satisfactory to the community, but not in a way which necessarily means the incarceration of young offenders. Everyone knows that to send a young offender to prison is likely to simply reinforce the criminal milieu in which that young person is operating, and in fact it can be a seminary for crime rather than a case of rehabilitation being offered.

PARA.TAB: At that conference a most interesting paper was delivered by a New Zealand judge who spoke of an alternative to imprisonment—a diversion into the community as it were. This alternative, operating particularly amongst the Maori population of New Zealand, entailed the operation for juvenile offenders of a shame culture whereby a young offender was brought face to face with family, with community and with those against whom he or she had offended. Therefore, the offender had to go through a situation of remorse and admission of wrongdoing, but in a way which then allowed the person to be reincorporated into that community. That seemed to many of us there to have much to commend it. In fact, in Wagga in New South Wales, I believe the New South Wales Police have adopted, with some modifications, a similar principle to divert young offenders from the system of imprisonment and incarceration.

I think it is also very important that young offenders be put in a position where later in adult life they can move into employment, education and other opportunities without the stigma of a criminal conviction attached to their name. For that reason, this Parliament has passed a law which, I think in relation to juvenile offenders who have committed a Federal offence, expunges that conviction so that it is no longer in need of disclosure when one applies for employment, education or some other opportunity in adult life. We know that in most cases juvenile offending is a transitory phenomenon and is not carried through to later life and therefore the stigma of conviction should not be an impairment or impediment to, and should not frustrate, reintegration into the adult community.

I believe there are many good steps which can be taken throughout the Australian community to deal with juvenile offenders and I believe that most honourable senators would applaud any step which diverts young offenders from the prison system, except in those rare cases where real violence is offered against the persons of those who are entitled to go about their social or business life without fear of assault.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister mentioned violence. Could he tell the Senate whether Ministers did in fact discuss the greater differentiation in sentencing options for violent and non-violent crimes, not just in relation to juvenile justice, but generally in the community?

—I believe there is a recognition throughout the community that imprisonment ought to be a sentence of last resort. In fact, in the Federal sentencing legislation passed by this Parliament, that particular injunction is made to the judges when they are sentencing Federal offenders. The prosecutor has to draw to the judge's attention that imprisonment is indeed a sentence of last resort. But, quite clearly, there will be instances in which imprisonment is appropriate, having weighed up the options of community service orders, a fine or some other penalty. Quite obviously, those penalties will be inadequate as an expression of the community's outrage and the need to contain somebody who has engaged in really violent activity. So in those situations it is justified. I believe that that general principle now has widespread support in the Australian community. It is one that certainly this Parliament has endorsed and that I support.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister seriously contend that he did not get it wrong on the Sunday program yesterday, as alleged by Mr Dawkins in the House of Representatives this afternoon? Given the conventional wisdom that the unemployment stabilising rate of growth is at least 3 per cent, which happens to be the Budget forecast for GDP growth for this year, does the Minister agree that if the growth rate does not improve on the annualised June quarter figure we can expect to see a deterioration in the unemployment rate for 1992-93 from the Budget prediction of 10.5 per cent?

—The Budget projections in terms of growth are for 3 per cent through the year, reaching a growth target of 3.75 per cent at the end of June 1993. As a lagged indicator in terms of recovery from the recession, employment is predicted to improve towards the end of the financial year as business activity improves. It is true that, if those predictions are not met in terms of growth, the predictions in respect of employment will probably not be met either.

PARA.TAB: As far as the first part of the question is concerned—whether I got it wrong—I have already said in answer to Senator Hill that I expressed very badly the point I was trying to make, which is that the 3 per cent growth rate that I always believed was very conservative was a through the year growth rate and that in current times we can only say that growth in the economy is taking place at 2 1/2 per cent. I expect that to improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that the 3.75 per cent figure is the target that would need to be achieved in order to ensure that the Budget prediction of 10.5 per cent in relation to unemployment is met? In other words, if he was despondent yesterday morning about its even reaching 3 per cent, does he therefore concede that there will inevitably be a significant growth in unemployment?

—Senator Alston has already put to me that what he describes as the stabilising rate of growth was 3 per cent in respect of employment. I think that is probably correct. In terms of exceeding that in employment growth, as I have said all along, I would hope for a higher rate of growth in the economy than the 3 per cent through the year.
—Does the Minister for Industrial Relations have any up to date information on where Australia stands on international comparisons of labour costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently, the US Bureau of Labour Statistics published a table which showed OECD countries ranked according to labour costs, including on-costs. In that table, Australia ranked well below the OECD average of countries. The findings of the United States Bureau of Labour Statistics show that, in 1991, hourly labour costs for production workers in manufacturing in Australia were 20 per cent below the OECD average. Australia ranked sixteenth out of the 20 OECD countries; that is, 15 OECD countries had labour costs which were higher than Australia's. The only countries which were lower were Spain, Ireland, New Zealand and Portugal.

PARA.TAB: On the issue of on-costs—that is, those other costs associated with employing labour, such as superannuation and workers compensation—Australia was well down the list of OECD countries. According to the United States table, on-costs in Australia, as a proportion of all labour costs, accounted for 25.3 per cent of total labour costs. In this table, Australia ranked fifteenth out of the 18 OECD countries, which was lower than Japan, whose on-costs were calculated at 41.8 per cent; the US, whose on-costs were calculated at 27.7 per cent; and the United Kingdom, whose on-costs were quoted at 26.9 per cent.

Those figures show that we have been successful in reforming industrial relations and making the Australian workplace more productive. They also show the lie that the Opposition sometimes peddles in this country—that labour costs in Australia are prohibitive. Compared to a series of like economies, labour costs in Australia are extremely competitive. Rather than run around this country condemning Australian workers, this is an occasion to congratulate Australian workers for doing a good job and achieving those figures, and urging Australian workers and their employers to work harder to put us at the bottom of this table to ensure that we have the world's most competitive costs on productivity. I think that that can be done as long as we maintain the level of industrial harmony that we have achieved in this country and work within the positive framework of generating a team approach to making our economy more productive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether the tables that he mentioned and the data contained in them have any implications for the concept and theory of workplace bargaining which is occurring in many places throughout Australia at the moment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —They do, but it depends on one's definition of workplace bargaining. Our definition of workplace or enterprise bargaining is to regard the award system, as determined by the Commission, as a system of minimum rates awards providing the safety net from which workplace or enterprise bargaining can be constructed. If, however, one is in Victoria—the attitude of the Government there being, as I am informed by Mr Howard, similar to or almost the same as that of the Federal Opposition—and enterprise bargaining seeks to tip everyone out of the award system, make their futures less certain and, with no protections, encourage that type of bargaining, then we will get a psychology in the work force that people will go for broke.

PARA.TAB: That means, I think, that because outcomes are less certain and there is a greater level of anxiety, there will be a higher level of industrial disputation, less likelihood of a team approach in the workplace, greater divisiveness in worker-employer relations and less of an opportunity for us to arrive at a competitive wage-cost scenario. Indeed, if the economy picks up in that situation, we would face what we saw in the last years of the Fraser Government—double digit inflation, a wages explosion and high unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows his answer to Senator Alston. How can the Prime Minister claim that Labor has saved Australia when the best the public can apparently expect from Labor, with unemployment rates at the highest levels in 50 years, is that those incredibly high rates of unemployment will be stabilised?

—In my answer to Senator Alston I said that I agreed with him that probably the growth rate required to stabilise employment was about 3 per cent. I said that I expected and hoped for better than that and that would be helpful with employment growth. In so far as the Prime Minister referred to the Labor Party saving Australia, the Prime Minister has—
—A colourful turn of phrase.

—Yes, he has a colourful turn of phrase and he also has a very keen grasp of the political history of this country. In using that expression, the Prime Minister was referring to the simple fact that the history of politics in this country, particularly under 27 years of conservative rule, was one of stagnation, introspection, protection—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, it was. If we look at the 1970s, Labor saved Australia from a continuation of a government that did not have the guts to do anything about tariffs, financial sector reform, so-called micro-economic reform and workplace reform, that had no wages policy and allowed wages to blow out to enormous levels in 1980-81 and 1981-82. It had no policies on any of those crucial issues which were of most importance to this country. Very importantly, that is what Australia was saved from.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition should listen to its own rhetoric today. Implicit in everything the Opposition says is, `We repudiate our past. We are different from the gutless Liberals of the 1970s. We are and will be tough. We will have an experiment which makes Margaret Thatcher pale by comparison'. That is what we will have under this new-beaut leadership, which Ian Macphee, a former Minister in the Fraser Government, referred to at the weekend as the hijack of John Hewson by right wing think-tanks. That is what has happened. That is the past which had to be repudiated. It is the past which the Prime Minister referred to in his comment last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister again seems to fail to appreciate that these record rates of unemployment are under his economic model and the results of his Government's policies, and all he puts to us today in his answer is further misery. When will his Government face up to the fact that it is its economic model that needs to be revised? In other words, when will the Government acknowledge the deficiencies in the economic model which have put so many Australians in this position of misery?

—We have a recession, which we have talked about in this place over a period of time. In the time of this Government, 1.6 million new jobs were created in Australia. Senator Hill puts himself in a competitive situation. He refers to our model, about which we have talked on a number of occasions here. He referred earlier on to the facts of the recession and the maintenance of interest rates at too high a level. We have talked about and debated that in the Senate over a long period. In Britain the model used has been the Thatcher model, which the Opposition now espouses to follow. That has led to nine quarters of negative growth in the British economy.

PARA.TAB: In putting forward and talking about the Opposition's alternative model, its own spokesman, even an honest one such as John Howard, apart from these illusory figures of two million jobs to be created by the end of the decade, says, `If we came to power tomorrow, we would be lying to the people of Australia if we said that we could fix unemployment in this country'. That is what he says. Look at the way the Opposition's spokesmen conjure up figures on unemployment. Seeking to make a point, Ian McLachlan, the honourable member for Barker, said a few weeks ago that 12,500 jobs have been created in the unprotected food processing industry, the implication being that there would be more jobs created in the food processing industry. He invented that; he made it up. It is not true; it is a false figure. Jobs are created in the Liberal Party by inventing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—During the recent visit of the Minister of Defence to Japan, did he discuss plans to develop joint exercises with Japan?

—The main purpose of my visit to Japan was to reciprocate a visit by its previous Defence Minister to Australia. I did notice on Friday that my counterpart in the Opposition, the shadow spokesman for defence, Mr Downer, put out a press release saying that a future coalition government would cancel all the plans that this Government has for joint exercises with the Japanese Defence Force. For the record, at no stage in Japan did I discuss with the Japanese defence agency, the Minister or anyone else joint exercises with its forces and Australia's forces.

PARA.TAB: What Mr Downer has put out, and a couple of people in the press have picked up, is totally false. A reading of the transcript from the press conference I gave in Japan gives a clear indication that joint exercises are ruled out. What we did decide was to bring forward the biennial meetings between the various members of the defence hierarchy to once a year in order to discuss the strategic issues of the region. Further to that, the only other decision we really made in that respect was to exchange views on peace-keeping forces. The Japanese have just committed themselves to the UN peace-keeping forces and seek our advice on our historical experience in this regard. Similarly, Australia is very interested in the views of Japan as a country that has committed itself for the first time and is coming as a new player into the field, if you like. So putting up the straw man that we are having joint exercises with Japan could have been avoided if Mr Downer had taken the time to read the transcript of my press conference in Japan. It is not true, it was never contemplated, never discussed and I doubt that it will be on the agenda for many years, if ever.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask the Minister: is it contemplated that Dr Anne Summers, currently an adviser to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, will be appointed as the new managing director of SBS?
—The appointment of the next chief executive of SBS is, as Senator Tierney should know, a matter for the SBS board and not for me or the Government.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister assure the Senate that the position of managing director of SBS will be advertised so that a wide range of high quality applicants can apply for the position, thus ensuring that the best person will be appointed?
—I will ensure that the chairman of the board of SBS, who is responsible for this appointment, is aware of Senator Tierney's concerns.
—My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. I refer to the application by some employer groups, currently before the Industrial Relations Commission, to delete existing—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mind, Senator? I refer to the application by some employer groups, currently before the Industrial Relations Commission, to delete existing superannuation entitlements from awards in the hotel, motel and drafting industries. I ask the Minister: will the Government oppose the application? Secondly, what would happen to the award superannuation of 80 per cent of the work force if the award system were abolished and replaced by a system of employment contracts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —When the history of the Labor Government in Australia in this term is written, one of the great social reforms that will stand out is the introduction of superannuation. Prior to the advent of this Government, superannuation went only to those workers who were in privileged public sector employment or in white collar employment and traditionally did not go to the vast bulk of the Australian work force. Under this Government that has changed and that is something to celebrate. For example, in 1983, only 24 per cent of all women workers had superannuation cover. Last November, that had increased to 72 per cent—a massive reform and a massive right and entitlement for those workers, many of whom are low income earners. The application by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry is to remove, as Senator Kernot has said in her question, the superannuation provisions of the award. We will oppose it strongly as a Government. We will oppose it because—
—Why do we need it with the SGC?

—Mr President, I take that interjection from Senator Alston, who asked, `Why do we need it?' For the simple reason, Senator, that the legislative minimum, under the now lawful provision, will be a foundation entitlement. However, where particular employers and particular workers want to vary their awards or where the Commission finds as a matter of fairness, justice and equity in the case of a particular industry that, upon argument, there is a case to vary an award to provide more, the Commission as the umpire should be entitled to do so, or those workers and employers should be entitled to agree to do so and put it in their award so that it is legally binding and forms the basis for an entitlement.

PARA.TAB: We will oppose the application because it is a nonsense application in my view. It seems to me that the Industrial Relations Commission has acted fairly and properly in directing superannuation cover in the way in which it has done.

Secondly, I was asked what would happen to 80 per cent of the work force if the award system were abolished and replaced by employment contracts. Again, it depends on what type of employment contracts. If they are employment contracts operating in our form of workplace or enterprise bargaining they will be safety-netted by the award, they will be secure and workers need not become anxious about loss of superannuation entitlements. If they are the type of workplace contract being suggested in Victoria, and which Mr Howard last week affirmed is the sort of approach he will adopt federally if, God help us, he ever becomes a government Minister, obviously, there will be great inequities introduced because there will be no award entitlement. Everyone will be tipped out of the award structure.

I noticed that on 21 June Senator Kernot put out a press release on this subject. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister provide details to the Senate about the national convention in Burma, which I understand will now be held by 10 January 1993? Can the Minister outline the guidelines which the Burmese State Law and Order Restoration Council has imposed on the convening commission; and is this representative of a positive step towards the restoration of democracy for the Burmese people?

—The State Law and Order Restoration Council, or SLORC, in Burma has announced the formation of an 18-member convening commission to organise the national convention on or before 10 January 1993. That commission will select participants for the national convention incorporating representatives of the remaining registered political parties, ethnic and other groups. The stated purpose of the national convention is to lay down guiding principles for the drafting of a new constitution.

PARA.TAB: The SLORC has enunciated a framework of objectives for the national convention. They include non-disintegration of the union; non-disintegration of national solidarity; consolidation and perpetuation of sovereignty; emergence of genuine multiparty democracy; development of principles of justice, liberty and equality; and also, rather less appealingly, participation of the armed forces in what is described as `the leading role' in future national politics.

Also, on the more positive side, I should note that it was recently announced that two martial law orders imposed in 1988 have been revoked—the most significant effect of this decision being to end the use of military tribunals, which have been responsible for most of the summary justice dispensed in Burma in recent times, including most of the sentences meted out to political prisoners. Again, 85 prisoners were released between 22 September and 1 October. According to SLORC announcements, that brings the total number of prisoners released this year to 572, including 38 elected representatives. Again, on 28 September, the SLORC did announce a re-organisation of local law and order councils under which army officers would be replaced by local administrative councils.

The announcement of a date for the national convention and the recent releases of political prisoners and other matters to which I have referred may constitute modest progress towards the long overdue process of democratic reform in Burma. But I have to say that it is still clear that Burma's rulers are not contemplating the early installation of a democratic government, with the result that, unhappily, it is only too likely that Burma's economy and human rights records will continue to languish among the world's worst.

No timetable has been set for a return to multiparty democracy. The objectives which, as I indicated a moment ago, were set out to guide the recently formed commission are ambiguous, referring on the one hand to multiparty democracy but on the other hand to the leading role of the armed forces.

Despite the revocation of two martial law orders, the apparatus of military rule by decree certainly remains in place and again, despite the release of political prisoners, more than 1,000 remain in detention or prison, including nearly 40 elected representatives and, of course, Burma's most popular political leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

Finally, Australia will be maintaining pressure on SLORC to effect early meaningful political change through such means as we sensibly can. In the Senate a few days ago, on 15 September, I outlined a number of additional steps which I have decided will be taken to that end. Again, it is worth saying that just a few days ago in New York at the United Nations I made some very strong representations to Burma's Foreign Minister and set out Australia's—and indeed international—concerns on all these matters.

—Last Thursday Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question about Medicare support available to couples trying to avail themselves of in-vitro fertilisation programs. I gave a pretty good answer, but I have received some further detail from the Department, and I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice, on 8 October 1992:

Is the Minister aware that there is a steadily growing number of married couples seeking to go on the IVF program? Is he also aware that these families are not able to adopt children, as there are no longer many babies available this way because of the increasing number of single supporting mothers and those having abortions? In view of the fact that the Government provides Medicare benefits for mothers seeking abortions, will the Government provide more funds to the IVF programs to enable more families to take part? Furthermore, will the Government consider providing Medicare benefits to cover the high medical costs for donors and recipients?
Senator Tate—The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the Honourable Senators' question:
The Commonwealth provides Medicare benefits and certain hormones to patients for assisted reproduction services such in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) and gamete intra-Fallopian transfer (GIFT).

The amount of benefit paid for a treatment cycle depends on the nature of the treatment. For a full uninterrupted cycle including hyperstimulation of the ovaries, oocyte retrieval, semen preparation, and transfer of embryos or gametes, the Commonwealth contribution would be about $2,800. Medicare benefits are currently available for six treatment cycles involving hyperstimulation of the ovaries in the patient's lifetime. Consistent with Medicare principles, all infertile couples are able to access assisted reproduction services under these arrangements.

In the first year of operation of the current Medicare benefits arrangements, from November 1990 to November 1991, approximately 11,500 patients received Medicare benefits for assisted reproduction services.

It is expected that the number of patients claiming Medicare benefits for assisted reproduction will increase in the current financial year as this is one of the most rapidly growing areas of the Medicare Benefits Schedule.
Because the majority of treatment cycles do not result in a maternity, the cost to the Commonwealth of assisted reproduction services per maternity is estimated at around $29,000.

Total Commonwealth expenditure in 1991-92 on Medicare benefits and hormones for assisted reproduction services was approximately $35 million. This figure excludes Commonwealth expenditure on normal antenatal care following assisted conception, treatment of complications of pregnancy, obstetric care, and care of the significant proportion of consequent babies which are multiple births and/or low birth weight.
This annual level of Commonwealth expenditure on assisted reproduction is significant at just over half of total Medicare benefits expenditure on obstetrics in 1992.

At present there is no plan to change the existing arrangements which provide substantial support for these procedures. However,the trends in usage of Medicare benefits for assisted reproduction and the complex issues surrounding these services are being kept under constant review by Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect Senator Bishop will be sorely disappointed, particularly when the electorate hears what the Liberal Party of Australia and its coalition partner are actually doing with the legislation which comes before them. What does the Opposition do with the initiatives which the Australian Democrats put forward in opposition to the Government? The Opposition does not vote with the Democrats; it votes with the Government. All those figures which Senator Kemp is so keen to trot out day after day really do not mean anything.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the substance. On 5 March 1992 the Democrats moved an amendment to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill requesting that families covered by the assistance for isolated children scheme—I would have thought that this would have been of some concern to the Opposition—should also receive the one-off bonus payment being made to family allowance recipients. But no, the Opposition voted with the Government against the Democrats.

Where does the Opposition stand now? On 1 April, the Democrats moved a motion that further reductions in tariffs should be suspended whilst the unemployment rate remained at such a high level. One would think that the Opposition would have some concern for the one million unemployed, but no, it has no concern whatsoever. The Opposition votes with the Government. It wants to cut tariffs. The Opposition does not care whether industries go into the ground. It does not care whether the one million unemployed becomes two million unemployed. Yet, the Opposition expects the electorate to vote for it. That is absolutely ridiculous.

On 29 April 1992, we moved a motion on the necessity of retaining the sugar tariff at its current level until the sugar industry's present crisis is resolved. I am very sorry that the National Party is not currently represented in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am here.

—I am glad that there is at least one representative in the chamber. I am sure that Senator Tambling will take a very active interest in this issue. Unfortunately, he could not find the courage to vote with the Democrats on that issue. Unfortunately, the coalition—the National and Liberal parties—did not have sufficient concern about the sugar tariff issue to vote against the Government. Even Senator Boswell voted with the Government to destroy the sugar industry in his electorate.

PARA.TAB: Finally—since we have been talking about the environment—the Australian Democrats moved amendments to the Ozone Protection Bill which sought to put CFCs, which deplete the ozone layer, and others which contribute to greenhouse gases, under the control of the Act. Once again, the Opposition voted with the Government to reject that amendment. That is the Opposition's concern for the environment—none whatsoever! I believe that the Opposition is rather too hopeful to think that the community can be fooled by mere figures that are drummed up, even if toes as well as fingers were used to arrive at the totals.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp seemed to be saying that I had supported Labor. He gave a strong impression that I had run around the country saying that people should vote Labor and that I had such enormous persuasion that, either single handedly or with my colleagues, I was effective in getting the Labor Party elected last time. Nothing could be further from the truth.

PARA.TAB: I have never been a member of any political party other than the Australian Democrats. As has already been pointed out, both personally and as a member of the Party, I have vigorously defended the Democrats practice of double-sided how-to-vote cards. It means that in those electorates where the predominance of votes will go back to one of the coalition parties that is exactly where our preferences go. In those electorates where there is a Labor—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. This has already gone past a personal explanation. This is now a debate on the merits or otherwise of the Democrats double-sided how-to-vote card. Therefore, I ask that you bring him to order.
—It is personal explanation and Senator Coulter should explain how he was misrepresented.

—The clear implication was given that I had supported the Labor Party, either as an individual or in my capacity as Leader of the Australian Democrats. I am explaining that in neither case did I do that—in fact, quite the contrary. As we believe in a democracy, we leave voters to determine where their other preferences should go.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that Senator Kemp again repeated the figures in relation to voting. He failed to point out that in his own table there were 86 occasions on which the Opposition has voted with the Government.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag (ANF).
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 85 citizens) and Senator Brownhill (from 231 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brownhill (from 52 citizens) and Senator Patterson (from 179 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Quarrying at Exit Cave
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, noting the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee concludes that `even under the strictest environmental conditions continuation of quarrying jeopardises the area's World Heritage values', respectfully call upon the Federal Government to take all necessary measures to prevent further quarrying at Exit Cave.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that the new rates for registered articles under Australia's Post's Print Post arrangements are unfair and discriminate against rural residents. The new arrangements will significantly increase the cost of magazines and newspapers for those who wish to receive them by mail and has the potential to threaten the viability of country newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the constitutional monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.

PARA.TAB: That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

TAB.TAB: The need to condemn the false expectations for growth and jobs promoted by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, as exposed by Senator Button on national television yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not only a matter of urgency, it is also a matter of the utmost importance to all Australians. It is a matter of the utmost importance even more to those one million Australians who are now officially unemployed and that further one million who are either hidden unemployed or underemployed.

PARA.TAB: The Keating Government is out of control—it has no strategy, it has run out of ideas, it is out of touch with reality, it raises false expectations only to have these cruelly dashed when the results come in, it totally lacks leadership, and no Australian can any longer believe anything that its leader says. Yesterday we had Senator Button go on national television and in effect imply these obvious facts. Yesterday on the Sunday program in a very illuminating interview Senator Button gave on Channel 9, amongst other things, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is the slow down in the world economy and nobody can say with certainty when that `but' will be removed from the discussion.
I mean we gave growth figures in the Budget forecasts. I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those now but as we move towards them employment will improve.
That was a quite unequivocal statement by Senator Button that, and I quote again:
I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those Budget forecasts.

Something happened between that statement and a few hours later because a few hours later Senator Button issued a press release which was headed, `Budget forecasts will be met says Button'. And that press release, amongst other things, followed on the theme of the heading and said, `So I believe that the targets will be met'.

PARA.TAB: There is no way in which the first statement that Senator Button made on television can possibly be reconciled with the statement contained in his subsequent press release. So the question is: why the change? Did he tell the truth the first time or did he actually get it wrong on national television and the right version is in fact what he put out several hours later?

Senator Button is the third most senior Minister in this Government. He is the Leader of the Government in the Senate. For almost a decade now he has been the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. He is very close, so he says and so it is said, to industry.

Is it possible to credit that Senator Button actually got it wrong the first time and then had to go and correct it? If so, how could this possibly have happened? Why yet again did he have to humiliate himself publicly by later putting out a statement totally opposite to his original one? Why did he change his statement? Who monstered him this time, I wonder? Who caused him to switch yet again like a chameleon from honest John in the morning on television to political John when he made his retracting statement in the afternoon? As Michelle Grattan put it in today's Age, that was a switch that even for Senator Button came `more quickly than usual'.

Senator Button says that the Prime Minister did not cause him to make his retracting statement—but is that really so? Was it someone on the Prime Minister's staff? We know that Senator Button spoke with the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, because he has said so and, indeed, today in Question Time he said that he had spoken to him twice. I think that when Senator Button responds in this debate, he owes the Senate and, through the Senate, the Australian people an answer to the following questions: when did he speak to Mr Dawkins; why did he speak to Mr Dawkins; and who actually rang whom?
I was intrigued to see the comments of Mr Dawkins reported in today's press. When he was asked what Senator Button had meant, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, I'm not quite sure what he meant. I saw what he said, but I don't know what he meant.
That sounds a little to me like, `Read my lips'. He went on though to say:
. . . that was one of the statements for which Senator Button has become famous over the years—entirely his own.

Mr Dawkins did not point it out, but it needs little recall to realise that over the years Senator Button has indeed made some stunning statements in the media and elsewhere which have put his Government into a situation of acute political embarrassment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly when he is right.

—More often, as my colleague Senator Michael Baume says, not because he got up and said the wrong thing but because he got up and said the right thing. He got it right, he was honest. That is one of the things that separate Senator Button from many of his erstwhile colleagues, not the least of whom is the now Prime Minister, Mr Keating. We all remember—and I still remember feeling myself blanch on Senator Button's behalf when I heard it—the Prime Minister making that absolutely blistering, cruel public and humiliating attack on Senator Button back in May 1990 when Senator Button was honest enough to talk about micro-economic reform and the fact that it was falling too far behind the pace.

PARA.TAB: But we do not have to go back to that time to remind ourselves of some of the other comments made by Senator Button. Less than two months ago he made various comments in relation to the Australian dollar because of his assessment of the prospects for the economy and the balance of payments outlook which put considerable pressure on the Australian dollar. A couple of months earlier, back in March of this year, he made various statements that accorded in very close degree with what the coalition has been saying about the appropriate approach to tariff policy in this country.

In May 1990, only a couple of years ago—and to me this is perhaps the most important of all Senator Button's expressions of honesty—he said that there were hard times still ahead. That was at a time, you may recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, when only two months before both the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, had said in the run-up to the March 1990 election that there would be no recession. The Treasurer indeed said, `We won't let a recession happen'. Only two months later in May 1990, Senator Button very honestly, frankly and correctly foreshadowed to the Australian people that there would indeed be some very hard times ahead.

So I come back to the question: why did Senator Button change his story yesterday; and who forced him to make that change? I look forward to Senator Button's honest response in this debate along the frank lines that he has been noted for and to which I have referred on this and other occasions. What Senator Button said yesterday on television was that he was, in effect, projecting a weaker recovery than that which was foreshadowed in the Budget. How do the Prime Minister's assertions last week of the recession being over long ago sit alongside this statement of Senator Button's—honest John not political John—on that occasion?

What Senator Button said yesterday should not have caused too much surprise to anyone. His original statement yesterday on television was by no means unreasonable. It is very much in accord with the facts as known of the state of the Australian economy, particularly when we look at the deteriorating situation and the deteriorating prospects for growth internationally. I agree completely with the Sydney Morning Herald which, in its editorial this morning, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Before he corrected himself, Senator Button was simply saying what many have been thinking as they have watched the economic outlook for the US, Japan and Europe deteriorate over the past month. Slower growth by the world economy will make it more difficult for the Australian economy to grow at the 3 per cent forecast in the Budget for this financial year.

That should be no surprise to anyone. If this Government were honest, if it were prepared to take the Australian people into its trust and into its confidence, it would be getting up and saying precisely that. Instead, we have had the situation where the Government has had dragged out of it a continually lesser series of forecasts for growth for this year and for that of the years ahead.

PARA.TAB: At the end of February—only six or eight months ago—the Government's One Nation statement forecast a 4.7 per cent economic growth for 1992-93. We told the Government at that time—as did virtually every economic commentator and certainly every businessman—that that forecast of 4.7 per cent growth for 1992-93 was absolute rubbish. There was no way in the world that that forecast would be met.

The Government itself has now accepted that. It came out in the Budget just six months later with a 3 per cent forecast—and even that, we said at the time, was almost certainly too high. It came out with that higher than reasonable forecast because it has one almighty hole in its Budget figuring for the next few years; it has an enormous gap between its huge spending programs, which are going to expand government expenditure enormously over the next few years, and the forecasts of the revenue it will raise to meet that expenditure.

The Government has gone for a huge `spend now, pay later' Budget policy, which has been its position for the last couple of years and which will continue to be its position in the future. The Government claims that it is going to be responsible and bring the Budget back into balance by the middle of the decade. But with growth down below 3 per cent that is impossible and, indeed, even at 3 per cent on the Government's own figuring, there is an irreconcilable hole in the Budget arithmetic at least over the period up to the middle of this decade and a cumulative deficit of about $50,000m.

We have had a deterioration in the Budget in the last two years alone of $17.5 billion. This year the Government is forecasting—and it is almost certainly a massive underestimate—a further deficit in the Budget of $13.4 billion, taking the deficit over the three years to this year to $30 billion on the facts and the Government's own figures.

We have never seen such a massive deterioration in the budgetary situation of this country. It spells two major inevitabilities over the next few years. One is a massive increase in interest rates and the other is a massive increase in taxes. Both of those must follow axiomatically from the decisions that the Government has taken and the policy path on which it is set.

We have seen amendment after amendment after amendment to the forecasts in terms of growth and Budget deficit size. Every forecast that the Government has made over the past several years has had to be massively revised, and even most of the revisions have turned out to be incorrect in the end as well. I hope that Senator Button—when making his honest, frank and pretty accurate assessment—will tell us today that the 3 per cent forecast for this year is unlikely to be attained. I hope he will be telling us whether that expectation on his part is on the basis of material that has been provided to him, a reassessment by his Department, or whether there have been any official revisions of the forecasts by the Treasury or any other official government agencies.

Certainly if one looks at the private sector which really provides the income and wealth creation, the profits, and therefore the job prospects in this country, one finds that the private sector is telling the Government that the signs of economic growth are almost non-existent. Last week several of the leading companies made statements saying just that. The company A.V. Jennings said:

SPEECH.PARA: Recovery could be up to 5 years away.
Pacific Dunlop, one of the most dynamic companies in Australia, said:
Economic recovery would not occur until 1995.
BHP made the following statement:
We expect the economic environment both domestically and internationally to remain subdued in 1992-93.
North Broken Hill Peko said:
The company's 1992-93 profit would continue to be hit by the recession. The largest retailer in Australia, Coles-Myer, said:
The retail world is collapsing around us.
That statement is well and truly confirmed and supported by today's retail sales figures which show virtually no growth at all in retail sales in the past month.

PARA.TAB: In the past when Senator Button has disagreed with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of the day, Senator Button is the one who normally has been proved right. I have already quoted to the Senate the `hard times' ahead forecast by Senator Button in 1990. He made it quite clear that we were going into a recession, a recession that at that time Prime Minister Hawke and Treasurer Keating denied would ever happen, because they would not let it happen.

I turn now to look at some of the untruths that this Prime Minister has delivered in recent years, particularly when he was Treasurer. Let us go back to 1990. In eight short months he made the following statements. The first one made was two weeks before the 1990 election:

SPEECH.PARA: We will not let there be a recession.
A couple of months later:
We are bringing home the bacon.

He said `These are beautiful figures' when the balance of payments deficit fell from something like $2 billion in one particular month down to $1.5 billion. Big deal! He is still running a balance of payments deficit of $18 billion or more. Then he went on say:
This is the recession we had to have.
He said that about nine months after he had said:
We will not let there be a recession.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has gone on to cover himself with equal glory in terms of his inability to state the factual situation par excellence in recent days. In the past week he said that the recession is now long behind us. Last week he had the hide to say that this Government had saved Australia. Saved Australia is right! The foreign debt is $150 billion, unemployment and underemployment represent almost $2 billion, the balance of payments deficit is still enormous, with collapsed investment around Australia and a huge, gaping and growing Budget hole.

We have a situation where Senator Button has blown the whistle on his Government. We have a government in disarray. It is a Government which is falling apart, it has no strategy, it is out of control and out of touch with reality. Senator Button himself said recently that the Government had gone as far as it could go on micro-economic reform. What absolute nonsense! What better indication do we have of a Government out of steam and out of hope. (Time expired)
