TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The burden of Senator Short's remarks is to say that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is talking up the economy when he says the recession is past us, and that, very kindly, I am possessed of some brutal reality which has a different view. He puts this argument based on what I said on the Channel 9 program on Sunday morning.

PARA.TAB: Let me say first of all that, if Senator Short reads the transcript of the Channel 9 interview, he will see that I put in context the remarks made by the Prime Minister last week. It is, of course, true that the recession, which was characterised by negative growth in the Australian economy for five quarters, has been replaced by growth in the Australian economy, and the economy is now expanding. That is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —By what rate?

—By 2.5 per cent. That is the best figure we can rely on at the present time, because that is the figure for the June quarter. Nonetheless, that is the only official figure we have and the economy is now expanding by 2.5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: That does not mean that the consequences of the recession which we had here are not still serious and difficult for many, many Australians. That is the case. The consequences are very severe and difficult for many, many Australians and that is why the Government put so much money in terms of stimulatory measures into the August Budget, particularly measures designed to stimulate employment through local government initiatives and so on.

That is why that was done, and that was opposed by the Opposition. Out of 13 interest rate cuts, six of them were opposed by the Opposition on the basis that they would be over-stimulatory of the Australian economy and that they would lead to excesses. That is why they were opposed. That is the Opposition's reading of the economy coming officially from the lips of their leader, Dr Hewson.
The Governor of the Reserve Bank made the following statement last week when commenting on this Government's record and on the policies which had been embarked on over a period of time:

SPEECH.PARA: Again, with the benefit of hindsight, it could be argued that certain taxes might have been increased to help counter the boom in the late 1980s or that some discretionary fiscal stimulus might have been taken earlier in the current recovery.

When the fiscal stimulus was introduced, it was opposed hotly by those opposite on the basis that this was the wrong thing to do because either the economy was recovering or, alternatively, they do not believe in the economy recovering, which is their option, I suppose, to help see themselves get elected. They do not believe the economy is recovering; they do not want it to recover. Six times that was done in terms of monetary policy and fiscal stimulus taken by this Government was opposed by the Opposition. As the Governor said:
Certainly, opponents of the monetary and fiscal policy easings have no right to be in the vanguard of those now voicing concerns about unemployment.

Senator Short made some play about the fact that on the Sunday program I said, as I did say—this was dealt with at Question Time—in terms of the growth forecasts, `I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those now but as we move towards them, employment will improve'. In that statement I was simply saying that the only figures we have now—I concede that I could have put it better—

TALK.START.PARA: —Pity you didn't say this then.

—I am not here for the personal edification of Senator Macdonald. Senator Macdonald always asks me to retire. Now he wants me to stay, I suppose, and support what he has to say. The only figure we have in relation to growth in the Australian economy at the present time is a figure of 2 1/2 per cent, which is not the 3 per cent forecast in the Budget. So I cannot say with absolute confidence that in this first period of the financial year 1992-93 we will attain the 3 per cent forecast, but I believe that through the year we will, and I have said so on many occasions. I have said—
—Why didn't you say so yesterday? Why didn't you say so on television?

—I have already said that I expressed it badly. Some members of the Opposition do it with monotonous regularity. I did it in the program. I expressed it badly, but I am concerned about what is the reality about the Budget and the forecasts.

PARA.TAB: Let me give honourable senators some examples of some people who do it and never correct what they say. For example, on 31 October last year Dr Hewson, the leader of those opposite, claimed:

SPEECH.PARA: On the Treasury's own index of competitiveness, today we are 15 per cent less competitive than . . . when the Hawke Government came to office.

He just misread it. In fact, Australia's competitiveness at that time had increased by 15 per cent. He misread it, but he was never prepared to admit that he misread the Treasury table. So he still runs around claiming the same figure.

PARA.TAB: In February 1990, a period in which Senator Short took some trouble to quote me, Dr Hewson claimed that in Australia we were heading `for double digit inflation'. Maybe he had Fightback in mind. Maybe he was thinking about a Liberal government of the future and thinking that we would have double digit inflation if he and his party got in. Maybe that was what he had in mind, but the fact is that inflation in Australia has not been at double digit level since this Government came to office and started to clean up the mess which we inherited from the conservatives opposite.

So in the art of forecasting or predicting what particular things will happen at a particular time, of course in politics there are all sorts of different views and views which change with circumstances. That is true of Dr Hewson as well as anybody else.

The words of the motion today represent in fact another effort from the Opposition to talk down the Australian economy. The 3 per cent growth rate through the year predicted in the Budget is not a high growth rate. It is not an exorbitant growth rate. It is relatively high by Australian standards, but it is not a huge growth rate. It is not a huge growth rate because we have had to take into account—and the OECD has had to take this into account in predicting various growth rate figures—movements in the world economy.

People in Australia often look to the British economy or the American economy to see what the effects are going to be in Australia, and they adopt a very gloomy view on the basis of doing so—and well they might. Britain has had negative growth—a declining or shrinking economy—for 2 1/4 years now, as distinct from ours which for the last quarters has been growing.

The fact of the matter is that it is not a reasonable method of assessing a potential growth rate in Australia to look purely at the United States with its huge international debt and its huge Budget deficit compared with Australia. It is not sufficient to look at the United States and Britain and draw these sorts of gloomy conclusions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the Japanese economy.

—My recollection is that Japan is still talking about a current growth rate of 2 per cent, which I think it believes will improve. There are all sorts of problems in the property market in Japan, but I do not think they have had a significant effect at this stage on industrial capacity.

PARA.TAB: The point about Australia's position, as distinct from the situation in the United Kingdom or the situation in the United States, is simply that nearly 70 per cent of our trade is conducted with economies of the Pacific region—which has been a huge structural adjustment under this Government—and 60 per cent of that trade is conducted with economies which have comparatively high growth rates: Taiwan, Korea, Japan—the lowest at the present time—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very low.

—I said the lowest at the present time. There is also China and, of course, the countries of ASEAN. All of those countries, compared with the United States and Britain, have relatively high growth rates. Japan is a little ahead of the United States and way ahead of Britain. Because of structural adjustments made in this economy and because of huge diversification of export capacity and so on, we find ourselves predominantly trading with the countries of the Asia-Pacific region which have relatively high growth rates.

PARA.TAB: So it is no good looking at the examples of the failed Thatcher experiment in Britain. As the Governor of the Reserve Bank said, when there are difficult times in the economy ideological prescriptions are not the ones needed. That is what those opposite are giving us in everything they say.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is simply not correct.

—Senator Short says that it is simply not correct. He came in here today and tackled me about micro-economic reform. Senator Short does not seem to know what micro-economic reform is. Tariffs are the pre-eminent element of micro-economic reform, and that is what I said.
—You think it's the be-all and end-all.
—I do not think that at all.
—That is what you said the other day.
—I do not think that at all; I have never said that. I did not interrupt Senator Short so he should not rabbit on too much. The fact is that he has had his speech—
—And a very good one it was.

—Senator Macdonald thinks it was a good one. That is what Senator Macdonald is elected here for: to loyally stick up his hand and open his mouth whenever he is told to, but not to make any intelligent contribution to the debate himself. He interjects all the time when I speak and when I answer questions; he approaches every problem with an open mouth and when Senator Short makes a speech he says, `What a beauty, Senator Short'. Because of that role he has crept forward from the back bench to the front bench where he can make more interjections.

PARA.TAB: I want to say a few things about substantiating the Budget forecasts. A sustainable housing recovery is taking place in Australia at present. In fact, the housing recovery looks faster than was forecast at Budget time. That is based on the fact that housing finance, local government approvals and commencements are improving. The Housing Industry Association's survey of volume builders for August shows continuing trend growth for sales and starts. Private housing approvals for the first two months of the September quarter were 13.1 per cent above the equivalent period a year ago.

Secondly, I agree that private consumption spending continues to grow at a modest pace, as we expected for this stage of the recovery. Business investment and employment will recover in the wake of an increase in GDP, which we talked about earlier in this debate. Indeed, in the Channel 9 interview, which Senator Short highly selectively quoted from, as did everybody else, I made that point about business anticipation and the sort of reports that businesses were making to me. Employment recovery is, sadly, a slow indicator following any period of recovery.

As I have already said, concerns about international economic conditions which affect Australian Budget forecasts ignore the fact that those Budget forecasts were not at the time based on an assumption of strong overseas growth. Much play is made of a difference in scenario one, as it was called, in the One Nation statement in February for an increase in growth of 4 1/2 per cent or 4.75 per cent—I forget which—and the subsequent growth figure forecast in the Budget that is affected by changes in the international economy. Changes in the international economy were taken into account in—

TALK.START.PARA: —You say those changes do not affect us because of the Asian situation.

—No, I did not say that. I said that we are less affected by those things. It is no good looking at John Hewson's Thatcher model in Britain to get a clear picture of what is happening because that is just a disaster area, as is the low growth of, and the failure to expand, the economy in New Zealand, where the Opposition's eyes are also sometimes cast. Concerns about international economic conditions were factored into the Budget forecast to which I have referred.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Short says, I know that some large businesses have said that economic growth will not be as fast as they anticipated. That is not the question; the question is whether we will attain the figure that was forecast in the Budget. That is the issue on which I part company with the Opposition; I maintain that we will attain that figure.

The September quarter surveys of manufacturers by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Westpac showed the best investment intentions response for two years. It is fair to say, as the Prime Minister said at the weekend, that the economy is growing and we are moving away from the recession. Some countries are not moving away from recession at all, but we are, although more slowly than anyone in the Government would like. But Australia is not any more an island economy as it used to be, remote from the influences, in part, of the world economy at large.

As I said on the Sunday program, the 13 monetary policy easings and the One Nation and subsequent fiscal measures will continue to help boost the economy. As I said earlier in this speech and on other occasions, it ill-becomes an opposition which has set up an alternative model of the economy to shed crocodile tears about unemployment and say that proposed interest rate cuts will have a very expansionary effect on the economy while it opposes increased government spending in the Budget to try to deal with unemployment issues.
This debate is the result of another occasion when one of my comments, which I concede was badly expressed by me, has been misunderstood and taken out of context.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lesson.

—No. Picked up on that basis, it has been used to try to create something for the Opposition to talk about instead of the Fightback package, which has just disappeared from the political agenda recently because it is not too popular. The Opposition does not talk so vigorously about it any more because the people of Australia understand that a narrow, ideologically based solution developed from the Thatcher Government of the 1970s is the worst possible solution for Australia in its present economic circumstances. Those opposite claim that giving us an additional tax on everything we buy will be the solution to Australia's problems. That is not so. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Button for finishing on that note, because it is the very point that I want to pick up—namely, it is a great pity that this debate today should have been couched in those rather narrow econometric terms which hinge on definitions of growth and economic indicators. It should have dealt with the far more important question, which is how we address the very severe social problems of this country and how we can put Australians before economic indicators and address the problems of fairness, equity and a fair go.

PARA.TAB: I accept the Opposition's criticism of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for saying that the recession is long over. Again, the Prime Minister was doing the same thing; he was simply pointing to that abstract, esoteric indicator that shows that there were so many quarters of growth as measured by economists, which was sufficient for him to say that the recession was over. He totally ignored the plight of the very many people who are unemployed and living in poverty and the very many single families and children who are living well below the poverty line, and so on. The really important issue is how we put Australians before these narrow economic indicators. I will return to that in a moment.

I did not see Senator Button yesterday on the Sunday program, so I am not sure whether he talked about expectations for growth and jobs. What I heard from the Opposition centred on expectations for growth. As I say, I will return to that matter in a moment.

There is no doubt that the economic growth rates in the One Nation statement were wildly optimistic, and I said so at the time. Senator Short mentioned that many other commentators at that time said that they were quite unrealistic. At that stage, the Australian Democrats called for a $6 billion fiscal expansion program to get employment growing strongly, but the Prime Minister only delivered $2 billion. We were right, and the Government had to adopt a more expansionary Budget. Certainly the Prime Minister should be condemned for the false expectation of jobs that he created at that time and for not following our proposals in getting to work to raise the money necessary for those jobs out of taxation rather than simply increasing the deficit.

The 4 3/4 per cent growth rate from One Nation was revised down to a more realistic 3 per cent in the Budget. Last year the Australian economy grew by 1.6 per cent but it is not outlandish to forecast a 3 per cent growth rate for this financial year.

What does this growth rate actually mean? It means an increase in the gross domestic product this year compared with last year. That gross domestic product is a dollar measure of all the goods and services which are made available in the country in that particular year, having taken out the inflation factors. So it means a real increase in the dollar value of goods and services. But we should note that it also includes a lot of bad things. When Senator Walsh was the Minister for Finance some years ago I asked him: where does the $6 billion that we spend on motor vehicle accidents appear in the national accounts? He pointed out, quite correctly, that it appears as an addition to the gross domestic product.

One of the things that members of both the Labor and Opposition parties seem to very willingly ignore is that both benefits and disbenefits, or costs, are included in GDP. It is possible to have our GDP growing and not necessarily have an increase in either employment or human welfare. As long ago as 1982, Barry Jones published the book Sleepers, Wake! and he pointed out that it would be possible to produce all the goods and services made at that time with some 6 per cent to 10 per cent of the population working if we were to go down the high-tech road and use all the gadgetry then available. One can easily imagine that it would be possible to have a `growing economy' with a very small proportion of the population working. Provided that the benefits in terms of some of the cash which was available was redistributed so people could buy those goods and services, one could have very low levels of employment and nonetheless have a growing economy.

In the late 1970s an American socialist, Morris Morris, worked out an index of human welfare, an objective measure of human welfare based on equal parts of literacy, infant mortality and longevity. He showed that there was no correlation whatsoever between economic growth or per capita GDP and human welfare. When he did this work in the late 1970s Sri Lanka came out very high on the index of human welfare but very low on per capita GDP whereas Saudi Arabia was very high on the index of per capita GDP but extremely low on the index of human welfare.

One needs to be extremely careful when both government and opposition simply use GDP or growth of GDP, which is what economists mean when they are talking about growth, as a surrogate for human welfare and link it in with ideas of jobs. We need to move away from that index and move more closely to one which is a real measure of human welfare. It is that measure which we need to move towards improving or increasing.

Senator Button's comments yesterday that the economy may not attain a 3 per cent growth target simply reflect the fact that at this stage he was being more candid than other members of the Government. Presumably, he has been advised of this lower than expected economic activity and as such the Government should release that advice and rethink its economic strategy. His subsequent statement that Australia is well placed to achieve the target simply reflects the pressure put on him by his own Party to not tell the truth. In this, we would agree with the Opposition. This shows the basic immorality of the Government's approach. The cartoon in today's Financial Review highlights the absurdity of this situation. It shows schoolboy Senator Button being caned by principal Keating and being castigated for telling the truth.

The real issue concerning the false expectations is the outrageous and callous remarks of Mr Keating last week to which I have already referred. His boast that the recession is over simply shows that he views Australia and the people of Australia as less important than these abstract economic indicators. The fact that the Opposition has raised this debate in those narrow terms indicates that the Opposition itself should be castigated for dealing with what has happened to those narrow economic indicators and not concentrating on the more substantial human issues.
At this point, I seek leave to move an amendment to this urgency motion.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, at the end of the motion, the following words be added:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government and the Opposition to abandon the use of misleading economic statistics, and to adopt new measures which accurately reflect social, environmental and economic progress.

Returning to Senator Button's assertion, we then have the most unbelievable assertion that the Government has saved this country. This is more than simply a cruel hoax; it is a delusion of grandeur. Exactly what have his economic policies saved us from? They have saved us from publicly owned businesses, they have saved us permanently from low unemployment, they have saved us from owning the businesses operating in Australia and they have saved us from being able to control the supply of credit and the interest rates in the economy. Of course, they are imposing on us the very high rate of reductions of tariffs. The Opposition would simply increase the rate of reductions of those tariffs were it to form a government.

PARA.TAB: The fact that the Opposition greets all this news with such glee—as I pointed out earlier, it voted with the Government on 86 occasions to impose these sorts of economic rationalist measures—is also a matter of concern. It is certainly true that the Opposition does not care about the unemployed because it opposed the expansion in this year's Budget. It wanted to keep interest rates higher for longer, as I think Senator Button has already pointed out, and it seeks to impose even tighter conditions on benefit recipients, including the possibility of throwing people off the dole after nine months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you ever oppose jobs at Marandoo, Coronation Hill and Shoalwater Bay?

—I am glad that Senator Macdonald has raised that because one of the areas that I want to turn to now is the area in which the Government should be encouraging the expansion of business. It should be moving into those areas. Dealing particularly with Western Australia, there should be strong central support for value adding, specifically in the area of the compact steel mill proposed either for Kwinana or Bunbury. This is an area in which one can very significantly value add to the iron ore which is currently being exported from Australia without any value adding. It is an area in which there is very significant employment to be had, certainly 10 times more than the proposed coal-fired power station at Collie, which the Western Australian Government has been promoting. It is also one in which there can be very significantly lower environmental contamination because the heat from that mill will be used for power generation, either 200 or 300 megawatts of power. It is an area in which one will bring together advanced technology which has not been brought together in any other steel mill anywhere in the world. That is the sort of proposition which I believe this central government should be strongly supporting. It is not a particularly clever country when the Government does not support those propositions of value adding and increased employment together with lower environmental contamination and the use of advanced technology.

PARA.TAB: I found it quite depressing going around car plants in recent weeks to find that BHP does not make the grade of steel necessary for the manufacture of a lot of car components. This compact steel mill will be able to do that and will also make steel suitable for the manufacture of whitegoods.

Very considerable possibilities exist in other areas. A major supplement in the newspapers at the weekend indicated the solar area where Australia has leading edge technology both in the direct conversion of solar energy into high temperature and low temperature heat for domestic and industrial purposes for the generation of electricity through that sort of technology and through photovoltaic technologies. We are not a very clever country when we turn our backs on the very excellent work being done by scientists and do not use that to develop industries.

We have the possibility in Australia of developing very extensive wind farms. Next to the Antarctic, we are the second windiest continent on earth. What do we do? We are waiting for that work to be done overseas and then we will import the technology. There are a few very small wind farms in Australia, but they are not nearly as extensive as they should be. The whole of the west coast of Tasmania, much of the south-west of Western Australia and the south-west coast of South Australia are excellent places for the generation of wind energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You oppose them on environmental grounds.

—Contrary to the interjection by Senator Kemp, we have been strongly promoting these in Getting to Work. These are the sorts of technologies which combine the provision of employment and the reduction of the foreign debt—it builds up industries in this country—and also addresses a very significant environmental problem, in that this Government, stupid as it is, is concentrating on developing the coal industry, something which those in the Opposition are supporting rather than going down this path of alternative energy.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wonder whether Senator Coulter might do the Senate the courtesy of providing a copy of his amendment.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—I believe that he is doing that now, Senator Short. The Deputy Clerk will have a look at it and then circulate it to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate the urgency motion that we are moving:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to condemn the false expectations for growth and jobs promoted by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, as exposed by Senator Button on national television yesterday.

Without wishing to be distracted for more than but a moment from the comments I wish to make, I refer for a fleeting second to Senator Coulter's comments. I notice that Senator Coulter agreed with us that Senator Button told the truth on television and changed the truth when he left the television studio about the level of expectation of growth in this period. Our view is that a growth of less than 3 per cent will be a disaster for the Australian economy. I do not know whether the Australian Democrats agree with that, but where we and the Democrats part company is on the Democrats' amendment where they are suggesting that we are using narrow economic and social indicators.

PARA.TAB: I can think of no other way of better articulating the social welfare of this country than looking at its level of growth. Senator Button says that we need 3 per cent growth just to stabilise employment or, to put it another way, to stabilise unemployment. If we do not have the growth, we do not have the jobs; if we do not have the jobs, then of course we will not have the social standards, social expectations and quality of life which, I am sure, even the Democrats would wish us to have. Senator Coulter talked about value adding and the steel mill in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the pulp mills?

—But he was talking at that time about the steel mill. They are all desirable ambitions, but until such time as Australia becomes more efficient economically and we get the cost and burden of government from the backs of businesses we will not have the sort of processing that Senator Coulter and we would want. Until we can do away with payroll tax and all the other burdens that are visiting business at the present time, we will not have the sort of growth that we want and the downstreaming of our products.

PARA.TAB: Is it any wonder that the Capri motor car, that little Ford sports motor car exported to the United States, can be driven off the showroom floors in Los Angeles with an air bag built in for $18,000 but that to buy the same car in Australia costs $28,000? That tells us something about our competitive nature and the need for us to become more efficient, effective and competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in US dollars?
—No, it is in Australian dollars in both cases. I agree with Senator Button, in his blush of honesty on television, when he said that he did not expect us to reach growth of 3 per cent. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We gave growth figures in the Budget forecasts. I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those now but as we move towards them, unemployment will improve.

He is saying that he has grave reservations about them; otherwise he would not have raised them. It was not a matter on the margin; it was a matter clearly of concern to him. That is, frankly, a view I have under this Government.

PARA.TAB: The acute embarrassment in which this Government finds itself as a result of a rare blush of honesty from Senator Button is that the truth has been exposed. As a result of that, Senator Button exposed the projections for what they really are. It is a great pity that Senator Button did not show the same honesty in the euphoria of the One Nation statement, the first statement made by this new Prime Minister, when the Government was projecting 4 per cent or 5 per cent, which was never going to be visited on this economy, although it suited the purpose for that modem.

Sadly, Senator Button's outburst of honesty lasted no longer than it took him to vanish from the glow of the television lights. We are now told that Senator Button, upon leaving the theatre of the studio, immediately repented and suggested that he had made a mistake. The only mistake that Senator Button made was that he told the truth.

As Mr Dawkins says, that was one of the statements for which Senator Button has become famous. What does Mr Dawkins mean? He means that every now and then as a result of an aberration Senator Button stands up and tells us the truth and causes grave embarrassment for the Government. Of course, Senator Button is in some respects a liability to this Government because he insists on these outbursts of truth from time to time. Does anybody seriously believe that Senator Button was in a flight of fancy and did not have good reasons and substantial evidence for saying what he did? Of course not. Has anybody suggested that Senator Button went on television and told a lie and then left the studio, repented and told the truth? Of course not. Senator Button simply forgot the Government's script. To suggest that he lied on television and then owned up afterwards is absurd nonsense. He told the truth on television and repented for his weakness later.

I notice that Mr Willis says that Senator Button was speaking for himself and not for the Government and was not expressing publicly the Government view. The truth, of course, is that Senator Button's portfolio requires him to rub shoulders with private industry and to consult with industry. It requires him to have some primitive knowledge of the circumstances of the economy. It is no doubt as a result of that knowledge that he felt, in his blush of embarrassment under the hot lights of the television studio, the need to own up.

Senator Button's Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is also that department which, on a daily basis, deals with business and private enterprise. I believe that they are telling him that the forecasted figures as given by the Prime Minister and the Government are not true and that they have given him their own assessments. As I say, Senator Button, in his rare moment of honesty, is nothing more than an aberration for this Government.

The history of this Government is one of cruel deception and dishonesty, creating false hopes only to have them dashed by broken promises. This comes from a government which pretends to be both open and honest. I quote Mr Keating in his very first days as Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make three commitments—
to the Australian people. He continued:
The first is I pledge to give everything I have got to the job and the country.
The second is to deal honestly with the people, to tell them the truth.

In tough times of course the temptation is always to gild the lily. I will be resisting that temptation as much as is humanly possible. I'll speak honestly with them, to them, and realistically, and I'll listen accordingly.

What Mr Keating was saying was, `Forgive me for all my past lies. Now that I am the Prime Minister, now that I have grabbed office from poor Bob, trust me for the first time and expunge all my dishonesty and my untruths of the past'.

PARA.TAB: However, let us look at the record of this Government and of this Prime Minister. I remind honourable senators of what he said immediately before ascending into the Lodge:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be no further challenge from me.
That was followed by the honesty of Graham Richardson:
The truth is that we were always going to challenge; the research made it legitimate.
Let us look at the economy according to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Here are some of his quotes:
If you look at Australia in a few years' time . . . you're going to see the Australian economy emerge as one of the most successful and balanced economics in the world.
The Government has not sat idly by and watched the nation's living standards decline. Instead we have acted decisively to turn the situation around. Tonight I can report that Australia is winning.
We are now well on our way back to prosperity.
In the Economic Statement of April 1989, the Prime Minister said:
That is why . . . Labor not only claims a superior economic strategy and performance—it has proved it.
In the Sunday Age of 11 March 1990, the Prime Minister said:

In the next term we will see investment coming up, the capital stock going into place, the production rising, the current account declining and inflation declining. When that happens, all of this imagery will change at such a pace that I really will have, I'm sure, some difficulty dealing with the popularity breakout.
In an interview on radio 3AW, that same month, he said:
No there'll be a slower year of growth, but there won't be a recession ahead.
In 1988, the Prime Minister said:
We are now well on our way back to prosperity.
In March 1990, he said:
We won't let there be a recession.
Then, but seven months later:
I knew there had to be a [recession] but I didn't want to tell you.
This is the man who says, `I am courageous enough to tell you the truth and tell it to you as it is'. Then on 5 December 1990, he said:
This [recession] is not a condition beyond control; it is a condition in fact engineered by the Government.
It was Mr Reith who, on 15 May 1990 in the House of Representatives, asked the following question:
Does the Treasurer agree with Senator Button's assessment that the Australian economy is in a state of severe downturn. If not, why not?
Rather than going through the whole answer, whereby Mr Keating disagreed with every single proposition that was put, I will just quote part of Mr Keating's answer. He said:
But my judgment is that the economy is slowing but it has not slowed to the point where we will have—I cannot remember the words he used—a recession or—
Mr Hawke—A severe downturn.

On 15 May 1990, we were not having a recession or even a severe downturn. Some months later we were plunged into a recession. One does not forget that it was this man who said in August 1988 on the Tonight program:
This is the one which brings home the bacon.
In 1985 Mr Keating said:
If we were providing these policy settings and outcomes in Western Europe, they'd be lighting candles to us in cathedrals.
Two years later, in the May Economic Statement, he said:
Tonight I can report that Australia is winning.
Then, at last year's Premiers Conference, he said:
The economy is now moving into the recovery phrase of the cycle.
Also in 1991, he said:
The worst is now behind us.
Yet another of Mr Keating's statements was:
These are definitely the golden years of change. Of course they are the golden years of change.

That is the history of this Prime Minister—call it confusion, call it doubt, call it dishonesty or call it incompetence. The truth of the matter is that this Government has never got it right and has never been prepared to tell the truth. The tragedy is that this is not the recession that we needed to have; this is the recession we needed to have because we had this Government.

PARA.TAB: The particular tragedy of this recession is that it is so different from all those that have gone before it. On this occasion, we are seeing the burden carried by the young and, in many respects, the middle management, white-collar, middle-aged and middle income earners. Those people will wear the burden of this recession for the rest of their lives; irrespective of whether the recession finishes tomorrow, next week, next month or next year.

The tragedy for these middle management people, these middle-aged people, these white-collar workers, is that they will probably never get another job in their lifetime; their skill, their ability and their experience are intrinsic to the company for which they have worked for probably 20 years; that is their knowledge of that company. Retrench them from that position and they are on the scrap heap. These are the men and women who are probably still paying off their mortgage, their children's school fees and mum's second car. They are now in a state of despair, doom and gloom as they confront the reality that they are unlikely to be employable again in their lifetime.

In a different way, the same circumstances visit the young people. There was a time when this Prime Minister was able to leave school at 14 and make his mind up as to what stream of employment he wanted to enter. When I left school, given commitment and hard work, I could decide whether I wanted to go into a profession, a trade, or the skilled work force—I had a choice. The tragedy is that the young people of Australia no longer have a choice. Thirty per cent of unemployed youth have never had a job. Many of them are confronted with years of unemployment. There are more than 350,000 Australian people who have been unemployed for 12 months. Australia has more than one million unemployed. There are more than 160,000 breadwinners who have been unemployed for longer than 12 months. More than 30 per cent of young people are unemployed as a result of the mismanagement, the incompetence and the corruption of this Government.

The truth of the matter was articulated by Senator Button on television on Sunday when he again said that the prognosis, as proffered and offered by this Government, shall not be that which will manifest itself at the end of this period. This Government deserves to be thrown out of office at the first available opportunity and I have no doubt that it will be by an unforgetting public.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Short

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a point of order. It relates to the amendment which has been moved by Senator Coulter by way of the proposed addition to the words of the urgency motion itself. The wording of the urgency motion is:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need to condemn the false expectations for growth and jobs promoted by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, as exposed by Senator Button on national television yesterday.
Senator Coulter's amendment proposes to add the following words:
The need for the Government and the Opposition to abandon the use of misleading economic statistics, and to adopt new measures which accurately reflect social, environmental and economic progress.
An amendment must be relevant to the question to which it is proposed to be made.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your advice on this, but it seems to me that the wording of the amendment as proposed by Senator Coulter has little, if any, relevance to the actual words of the urgency motion as outlined by me and as contained in the Notice Paper. I seek your guidance on this, but it does seem to me that there is a real question of relevance on this occasion in Senator Coulter's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you taking that as a point of order?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Yes, I am, and I am going to rule on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —If so, I wish to speak to that point of order. The urgency motion talks about `false expectations for growth and jobs'. The point that I made in my speech made it absolutely relevant, and showed quite definitively, I think, that growth is measured as an increase of GDP and that there is no correlation whatsoever between the increase or decrease of GDP and jobs. Therefore, the indicator which is implied in that is just as misleading as the claim that Senator Button himself was misleading. Therefore, the amendment is absolutely relevant to the motion.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members themselves have used the words `false expectations'. The implication is that if a different measure of growth was put in there, there would be true expectations. My point is that because the index itself is misleading, the amendment is absolutely relevant and, therefore, the Government and the Opposition should abandon these misleading economic statistics and adopt new measures.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what you say, Senator Coulter. I was considering the matter before you rose. I think in the motion there is the inference that statistics have been used. Percentage of GDP has been used in all the speeches I have heard so far. If the Senate reflects on decisions that have been made before in this place, it will see that they tend to err on the side of letting people put their view rather than taking a narrow interpretation of that view. Odgers says:

INTERJECT.PARA: This approach best serves the Senate's function as a House of review, and to this end it is reasonable to allow a Senator an opportunity to connect his remarks with the subject-matter of the Question before the Chair.
Under those circumstances I think I will allow the amendment and I will call Senator McMullan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President, if not with the amendment. The amendment raises some questions which go to the heart of what is wrong with the resolution, even though I profoundly disagree with some aspects of the amendment, particularly the implication that the statistics are misleading. They may not be sufficiently comprehensive—it may be that there are other things that need to be measured—but they are, of themselves, internationally regarded as some of the best statistical bases for economic and other policies in the world.

PARA.TAB: What it does go to is that what we are getting bogged down in here is a debate about the semantics of the matter; about whether somebody expressed himself inaccurately and inelegantly; and about the behaviour of individuals over a number of years as to whether they have had a habit of doing so. I think what the Australian people want from us and from this Parliament is a discussion about the policies most suited to dealing with the problems that they see us confronting.

I made a speech in a forum in this building on Friday night about ways in which we might enhance the role of the parliament by involving it in debates about national issues in the struggle for ideas that is going on in society between the policies advocated by the Opposition and the Government, and alternative viewpoints that are not reflected in either. I have to say that the debate about this particular urgency motion and, with respect to Senator Coulter, the amendment, does not fit into that category. It is bogging us down in the semantics and in the detail. Let us get down to the policies.

I have to deal briefly with part of the detail of the motion before I get to what is behind it. Senator Button has obviously made it clear at Question Time and in his contribution that his view is that the Budget forecasts will be met. That remains the case and it is quite clear that that is the unified view of all on this side. It is consistent with everything else that he said. The transcript of his contribution to that debate shows that that view is consistent.

The way in which this sentence, when taken out of context, can give a misleading impression arose as Michelle Grattan—using a phrase which I cannot use because it is distinctly unparliamentary—summed up in the words Senator Button used when he came out of the interview. That explained how this took place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he really say that?

—It is in a journal of record whose words I am prepared to accept. It is entirely consistent with what Senator Button said today and what he said about the evidence from business and the increased stimulus to come. The key issue before us really is not what words Senator Button, Dr Hewson, Mr Keating or Mr Reith might have used to describe projections, which are not really very far apart, about what is likely to happen in the Australian economy. The projections Dr Hewson made after the Budget and those the Government made in the Budget are very close together. What we really want to know is what is the likely outcome, and what are the policies likely to lead to the most favourable outcome.

PARA.TAB: An international perspective is always helpful—people outside Australia looking at how our policies are going and what our prospects are, and delivering their judgment. In the brief time available I was able to pick up two respected analysts' views. The AMEX Bank Review of July 1992 surveyed five countries—Australia, the USA, Canada, the UK and Japan. The best prospects for a stronger performance in the next 12 months are in Australia, followed by the United States and Canada, with the UK trailing and Japan far behind.

It then goes on to look at the reasons for this. It says that three real sources of economic growth in the Australian economy give us the best prospects. They are consumer confidence, fiscal policy and, overwhelmingly, monetary policy. We have a contrast between Government and Opposition in those areas. In the area of consumer confidence I think there is room for speculation about whether there would be differences between Government and Opposition. It depends on one's view about the GST, which is an issue I am happy to debate but which takes us off the subject.

In the area of fiscal policy and monetary policy there is no room for doubt about the distinction. The Opposition says there should not be fiscal stimulus, and the independent bank review says quite clearly that that is a plus for economic growth in Australia. I think every responsible economic commentator says that, at this stage in the economic cycle, it is the appropriate and responsible thing to do to provide fiscal stimulus. Other governments of much more conservative political persuasions are doing the same, including the liberal-democratic party government of Japan, the conservative party in the United Kingdom and the conservative government in Canada. On monetary policy the United States, Canada and Australia all get double pluses for very stimulatory monetary policies.

The Opposition strongly resisted the initial decisions by the Government to lower monetary policy. Dr Hewson strongly opposed those decisions and said they were just political—just designed as a matter of politics, not good economics. He did not think we should have been reducing interest rates when we did, and he opposed the first few of those reductions. All the objective evidence is that it is clear there would be an increase in interest rates under the Opposition's policy, for reasons which others have articulated and which I have not got time to do today. It is clear that the American Express Bank says that Australia has the best prospects of recovery of any of the major economies it surveyed.

It is not only Amex. The Economist on 8 August surveyed the 13 leading world economies of which Australia is one. It took a poll of forecasters around the world and asked, `Which economies do you think will perform the best in the next two years?' In 1992, which economy did they predict would have the best economic results? Australia. In 1993, which of those 13 leading economies did they think would have the best result in the world? Australia. That is not to say they think that happy days are here again and there will be no problems again. They are saying 2.5 per cent for 1992 and 3.7 per cent for 1993. When one thinks about that, it quite clearly says they are predicting about 3 per cent for 1992-93—the Budget prediction. More importantly, their prediction is that Australia will be the most successful of all those economies in terms of economic growth for the next two years because of the policy of the Government.

There is need to do more—that is not a ground for complacency—but it is an indication that we do not have to hang our heads in shame. The world is in an economic slow-down and it is very hard for any country to grow quickly within a world economy growing very slowly, but within the limits imposed by that international constraint, we are doing, comparatively, very well.

Let us look at some of the major forecasters in Australia. They have, as the Government has reflected in its projections during the first half of this year, revised down their growth assessments a little. Both the bodies I will quote—Westpac and the Commonwealth Bank—have revised down their growth forecasts for 1992-93. What are they predicting now? Westpac is forecasting for 1992, 1.7 per cent and for 1993, 4 per cent. That is slightly down on what they were predicting before, but when you think about what it reflects for the average for 1992-93, it is about 3 per cent. They are saying, essentially, that the Government's predictions are on track but the growth will be more in the second half of the year.

The August 1992 Economic Newsletter of the Commonwealth Bank says that the Government's projection for 1992-93 is too conservative and that, in fact, growth will be 3.3 per cent. That is revised down on the bank's previous estimate. We have all underestimated the nature of the international effect and probably put too much confidence on a rural upturn that has not yet been reflected this season. Growth prospects are not as good as we thought at the start of the year, but the general consensus is that 3 per cent is certainly not ambitious; it is on the modest end of the range of industry predictions.

It is not surprising because if we look at the secondary indicators, at the indicators that suggest where growth is going, where the economy is going, they all suggest that there is a modest recovery under way, that the fundamentals are right. The most worrying and difficult of the economic criteria relates to jobs. This area has the most profound social consequences. It is always the slowest to recover from a recession. The job figures are the last to fall, but also the last to rise. Disturbing and worrying as those figures are—nobody can underestimate the problem—the employment trend is clearly up and there are tentative signs that the job advertisements are starting to increase. The figures are indicating an improvement. That is exactly what one would expect, because the figures are showing that GDP has been growing since June of last year and also that gross non-farm product is growing strongly.

If we look at other figures, like the trend line of the turnover of retail establishments since June of 1991 or that of motor vehicle registrations or dwelling approvals, each of these bounces up and down month by month for a variety of seasonal reasons and, when they are seasonally adjusted, for a variety of statistical reasons because they are sampling. But the trend line is clearly positive. Even in those areas that have been very slow to improve, like manufacturing production and new capital expenditure, the seasonally adjusted indications are that the first signs of improvement are emerging.

Of course everybody wishes the growth rates were higher. I think even Opposition members wish the rates were higher. They have a political wish that they were not, but they are citizens; they would like to see their friends and relations able to get jobs too. Perhaps I am being too positive about them. There are those who think those opposite sit over there, as Senator Button once so beautifully described it, `buoyant with gloom'. I would be the last to say that about them.

It is quite clear that the tentative signs of improvement are there. It is also quite clear that we wish growth rates were higher and that we should be doing more to stimulate the economy. That is why the significant issue is not what Senator Button said on Sunday; it is what the respective policies of the alternative governments suggest for the future of the Australian economy. It is why it is very important that we continue with monetary policy that continues to provide stimulus. That is what we have, because we can deliver low inflation and therefore we can deliver low interest rates and people who wish to invest can do so at a low cost of money. That is not possible if one introduces a GST in these circumstances and jacks up the price levels. Even if, in the most optimistic expectations, one can get it out in 12 months—I do not share that view, but let us assume it is right—it has a temporary impact and it means one is asking people to lend money at a negative rate of return; that is, if the Opposition is going to keep the rate of interest as it is now, and it will not do that.

We need a stimulatory fiscal policy, not a proposal to cut $6 billion to $10 billion out of government outlays and reduce the government stimulus from the economy—the classic prescription of the 1930s which has not been adopted by anybody since. Not even Margaret Thatcher adopted that policy. We need a recognition of the role of wages policy in generating economic growth and we need a balanced approach to tariff policies.

We have had a lot of speculation that the people who criticise Fightback are some sort of left wing conspirators. It may be that all those banks I cited earlier are part of a left wing conspiracy; it may be that the Australian Bureau of Statistics—which showed all that data about the improvement in the indicators—is part of the left wing conspiracy. Maybe even Mr Ian Macphee, who said that the Opposition's policy has been hijacked by right wing think tanks, is part of a left wing conspiracy.

There is a proposal that the Federal Liberal Party's Fightback package of economic reforms is to cost tens of thousands of manufacturing jobs. I do not think the architect of that is a member of any left wing conspiracy because that comes from the Leader of the Liberal Party in South Australia. That is why we need to be concerned not about who said what to whom yesterday. We need to be worried about whose policies are more capable of providing economic growth for Australia into the 1990s.

We have the stark contrast in monetary policy, fiscal policy, wages policy and tariff policy. It is who has those policies to create jobs for tomorrow. Growth is under way; we have been growing for quite some time, but we are growing too slowly and we need to give more stimulus to the economy. That is the choice. That is what the debate in this Parliament should be about. It is a pity we continually get diverted by these semantic quibbles about who said what to whom yesterday. It is of great fascination to those opposite; it is the contemporary equivalent of how many angels can dance on the head of a pin. Let us get the Parliament back to the issues that worry the people out there in the street, and that relates to whose policies are most likely to create jobs for today and tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sat here for 15 minutes listening to Senator McMullan telling us that his monetary and fiscal policy was correct and—he did not quite say that, but using his Leader's words—that `it had saved Australia'. I ask Senator McMullan to tell the people of Australia—if his monetary and fiscal policies have been so successful—why there are now almost two million of our fellow Australians unable to get the hours of work that they need. Why are almost one million of our fellow Australians officially on the unemployment queues? If Senator McMullan's Government has done so well with its monetary and fiscal policies, why are we in the mess we are in? Why are we, to use the words of Senator Walsh, in an economy that has been `stuffed'? I ask Senator McMullan to explain that to the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan did mention the consumption tax, the GST. I found his words on that subject very amusing, seeing it was only a few short years ago that his Leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), was the leading protagonist for a consumption tax. His Leader argued the subject very, very well. Some of Mr Keating's words are words that I use when I go around the countryside promoting the GST, because he promoted it so well in 1985; but we was snowed, he was done over by the ACTU for purely political reasons. My colleagues from Victoria tell me, however, that his replacement is such that maybe I should not be so urgent in my suggestions that he retire early.

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll be sorry when he leaves—especially when we see the alternative.

—I believe the alternative was one of the architects of the Victorian economy in recent times, so maybe seeing him is a pleasure in store. This urgency debate is a matter which does require the most stringent examination and adoption in that we expose the statements of Mr Keating that are absolutely breathtaking in their sheer arrogance and hypocrisy.

PARA.TAB: It is essential that those statements be exposed. I refer to the statement made by Mr Keating, `The fact is that this Government has saved Australia'. Tell that to the one million unemployed. Tell that to those whose whole life savings have been ruined by this Government in bankruptcy. And that further statement by Mr Keating, again breathtaking in its arrogance and hypocrisy, `We were out of the recession long ago'.

Those statements have to be exposed for the recognition of the people of Australia. They are just two statements in a long line of breathtakingly deceitful statements from this Government—statements like, `No child will live in poverty'; `There will be no recession; We will not let there be a recession'. Statements like that made by the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, the head of this Government, who said, `I will be leading you at the next election', just a short time after he had promised Mr Keating and his union mates that he would step aside and give Mr Keating the Prime Ministership. That sort of breathtaking hypocrisy and deceitfulness must be exposed to this nation.

The statement by Mr Keating, that the recession finished long ago, is a cruel hoax. Such statements are a cruel hoax on the unemployed, small business, tourist operators, farmers and welfare agencies because they give the unemployed some wrongful hope for the future. The despair that they suffer daily is wrongfully dealt with by Mr Keating. The unemployed are given some hope when Mr Keating knows they have none. They are given a false sense of hopefulness—something that they might be able to look forward to, and it is entirely false.

It is a cruel hoax on small businessmen who want to expand, who want to try to get their businesses going, who might happen to believe that the recession is finished and might want to get ahead. It is a cruel hoax on tourist operators who are looking for the people driving up to their resorts and do not see them coming. They wonder what is happening when Mr Keating has said he has saved Australia, when Mr Keating has said the recession is finished but there are no more people coming to their tourist facilities. And it is a cruel hoax on the welfare agencies, the people who hope to have some relief from the daily despair that they see of people whose lives have been absolutely shattered by the actions of this Government.
How do we know that it is a cruel hoax? We know it is now a cruel hoax because Senator Button exposed it on the Sunday program. As Senator Button said on that program:

SPEECH.PARA: I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those Budget forecasts.

Senator Button has exposed Mr Keating for what he is, but he is not the only one. Senator Button has this record, as Mr Dawkins said, of making these statements. On 29 May 1990, when talking about Government estimates, Senator Button said:
It is pretty clear to anybody who can do arithmetic that the Budget forecasts in respect of the current account deficit cannot be met.

So it is certainly not the first time that Senator Button has made those statements which have tried to put some realism into the exaggerated statements that Mr Keating has made. Senator Walsh, who follows me in this debate, has also exposed the Government for its hypocrisy in the statements it has made. Not too long ago Senator Walsh said—and no doubt he will mention it himself in his speech—that Labor had `stuffed Australia's economy' and he warned the Government that the One Nation statement was based on rubbery figures.

PARA.TAB: On 31 March this year in the Australian, Senator Walsh said he doubted whether the Government's growth forecasts of more than 4 per cent could be taken seriously. On one of the Government's proposals he further said that the decision to spend an additional $602m on roads over three years was suspect, adding that the original so-called black spots road program was opinion poll driven. He further said that Mr Keating was deluding himself by refusing to believe Australia was heading for a recession up to the end of 1990 and he suggested the Prime Minister did not really believe in the decision not to reverse the ban on mining at Coronation Hill.

Senator Walsh is quoted further as saying that the tax cuts could not be underwritten by the 4 per cent plus growth forecasts in One Nation. He said, `That was the figure which was cited, but I doubt that it should be taken seriously'. So there was Senator Walsh as well exposing the untruthfulness of these statements by Mr Keating. If one needs any further exposition, one has only to look at the facts.

In the 1991-92 Budget there was a growth forecast of 1.5 per cent, which came down in the One Nation statement to zero per cent. In the 1991-92 Budget there was a deficit forecast of $4.7 billion, which in the One Nation statement increased to $6.8 billion. In the 1991-92 Budget the result was $9.3 billion. So it went from $4.7 billion to $6.8 billion to an actual of $9.3 billion.

In the 1992-93 Budget the growth was forecast at 3 per cent, although Senator Button is now calling that into doubt. In the One Nation statement, of course, it was forecast at 4.75 per cent. In the One Nation statement the deficit was forecast at $8 billion and in the 1992-93 Budget the deficit was forecast at $13.4 billion.

So one can understand why Senator Button and other people on the Labor side are confused as to which estimates might be right. One can understand why Senator Button comes out and exposes the crueler hoaxes of Mr Keating when he talks about the recession being finished. It is necessary and urgent that we expose these expectations of growth and jobs for the hoaxes they are because the Australian people must understand the lies and the misinformation—deliberate untruths—that this Government is perpetrating on the Australian public.
It really does not need much going back in history to look at the statements that Mr Keating has made. Going right back to 1983-84, when he was talking about the Budget, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be a considerable improvement in the coming year.
In that year the foreign debt rose from $23 billion to $29 billion. In the 1984-85 Budget, he said:
The Government's policies are now on track.
And in that year the foreign debt rose to $51 billion. In the next Budget, he said:

And the foreign debt in that year rose to $76 billion. In the next Budget for 1986-87, he said:
My plan for this year is a more robust economy.
And the foreign debt rose to $86 billion. In the 1987-88 Budget, he said:
Tonight I can report that Australia is winning.
And the foreign debt rose to $96 billion. And so it went on. In the 1988-89 Budget, he said, with again that breathtaking hypocrisy:
We are well on the way back to prosperity.
And further:
This is the one that brings home the bacon.
And all that happened was that he bought a pig farm. Then he said:
Our foreign debt has begun to fall.
But the facts were that our foreign debt rose to $117 billion and 7,435 businesses became bankrupt. And he later said in the 1989-90 Budget Speech:
As a result of the Government's economic policies Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession and with its economic and social structures improving.
And following that, the unemployment rate rose from 6 per cent to 7.3 per cent and another 122,000 Australians joined the dole queue. And so it went on. In the 1990-91 Budget Speech, he said:
This year our financial situation will markedly improve without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

That was just in 1990 and in that year the unemployment rate rose from 7.3 per cent to 9.8 per cent and another 225,000 Australians joined the dole queue. So how can one believe anything that this Government says?

PARA.TAB: There is a need to expose these statements because people do take notice of them. Does not the Government understand that as a result of those sorts of outrageous statements made by Mr Keating people do alter their position to their detriment? There is a need to condemn and expose these expectations of growth and jobs so that the people of Australia can understand what a mess this Government has made of the country in the last decade and that at all costs they must get rid of this Government at the next election. There is an urgency to save Australia, to implement some policies that will do something for Australia and to expose the lie that there can be any growth and jobs while the Labor Party remains in power.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you know that `growth and jobs' and `Labor' are mutually exclusive terms. The only growth and jobs we can get is if some Government has the courage to get rid of the dead hand of bureaucracy from the Australian economy, to slash income tax, to slash payroll tax, to cut the 26c per litre fuel tax, to get rid of the training guarantee levy and to abolish sales tax. Only when a Government can do that is there any chance for growth and jobs in Australia. There is only one party in Australia that will do that—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion which has been moved by the Opposition is an assertion supported by a lie. The assertion is the false expectations for growth and jobs promoted by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the lie is as exposed by Senator Button on national television yesterday. Senator Button on national television yesterday did no such thing.

PARA.TAB: We have all heard many times the loose line that Senator Button himself, I am sure, would describe his comment as. What nobody in the Opposition has quoted is that Senator Button also said on the same program:

SPEECH.PARA: What seems to me to be happening out there is that with many businesses with whom I talk—their bosses—they say that their sales are improving, their profits are quite good but that is not yet reflected in their capacity to take on new employees.

Returning to the Sunday program, about three years ago I began to ask myself: why do politicians keep going on that program? I decided—and I was still in the Ministry then—that I would not appear on that program and, for as long as I remained in the Ministry, I did not.

PARA.TAB: The question that I then put to myself still puzzles me: why do politicians go on that program when they know that the whole of Canberra's press gallery and a number of people outside Canberra, if they do not actually watch the program, get a video of it, read the transcripts and search through diligently to see whether they can find one loose line, one loose sentence or even a loose phrase which they can then take out of context and beat up in all Monday morning's newspapers, on the ABC AM program and all the rest of them.

Sunday is usually a pretty slack news day and those journalists habitually feed off the Sunday program. What gets published on Monday is at best a gross exaggeration and, indeed, often if viewed in context, a complete misrepresentation because journalists focus not on the entire content of a 10-minute interview but one thoughtless line or a loose or imprecise sentence. Senator Button himself has acknowledged that he should and could have put the point he was making better and more clearly than he did.

Therefore, as everybody knows that that is the case with the Sunday program and the press reporting of it, why did those opposite move this urgency motion today? The answer to that, I suggest, is that they knew Michelle Grattan would bucket them and say that they were a bunch of dills if they did not—and she probably would be right. But, because those opposite have moved this motion, Michelle will not bucket them tomorrow and say that they are a bunch of dills because they let Senator Button get away with this loose line and did not try to beat it up into something much more important than in fact it is.

The subject, in so far as it does have any context in the debate, is of course economic forecasts or the type of economic forecasts that are contained in Budgets. Economic forecasting at any time is an imprecise science, even in Budget-type forecasting which is rarely projected more than 12 months ahead. Long term economic forecasting, defined as 10 years or more, is sophistry or worse. Indeed, taking money for long term forecasting is tantamount to theft because, by the time the forecaster is proved wrong, everybody has forgotten the content of the forecasts anyway and whoever received the money is no longer in business. I repeat: taking money for long term forecasting is tantamount to theft.

Having said that, I do not imply that there is absolutely no merit in forecasting or in attempting to make forecasts or in attempting to measure economic variables after the event. That leads me to the amendment moved by the Democrats which wants to trade off the imperfection of economic forecasting for the imprecision and warm cuddly nonsense of trying to embrace within it things which cannot be measured—and of course the Government will not be accepting that.

Treasury has often been wrong with its economic forecasts, sometimes quite seriously wrong. I hasten to add that the Treasury's record is certainly no worse and, indeed, I believe a careful analysis would show, is considerably better than that of forecasters outside of the Treasury, some of whom have the effrontery at times to be critical of Treasury for its inaccuracies.

When 11 months ago the then Treasurer John Kerin at a press conference was asked, `Has the recession ended?' or some question like that, he answered, `Your guess is as good as mine'. He got ridiculed for that answer, but it was in fact a very sensible and honest one to make because at that stage nobody knew for certain whether, even in the technical sense, we had moved out of the recession—that is, having had two consecutive quarters of positive economic growth—but we do now know that, shortly after Mr Kerin said that, we had in the technical sense moved out of the recession.

Having knocked back numerous invitations to poke my face in front of a microphone and/or a camera and adjudicate on this alleged discrepancy between Senator Button's view of the world and that of Mr Dawkins or the Prime Minister or someone, I was asked today by a journalist, `Do you think that the growth forecasts will be met?'—that is, in this financial year. I said, `Your guess is as good as mine'. Then I thought again and said, `No, your guess is probably better because you have been studying the recent economic statistics more diligently than I have'.

Sure, in the lifetime of this Government there have been a number of Budget forecasts which have differed quite substantially from the Budget outcomes. Foremost among those, I hasten to point out, is that until the last two financial years the bottom line of the Budget, the deficit or surplus, whichever way we like to look at it, came out much more favourably—that is, if the objective is to improve the Commonwealth's financial position—than the forecasts which were made at the time the Budget was introduced had anticipated. But it predates this Government.

We heard a fair bit about Budget deficits from Senator Macdonald, I think it was. The last Budget brought down by the Liberal Party—the disgraceful 1982 Budget which was bereft of any sort of economic strategy, which contained only a political strategy which consisted of a sequence of bribes designed to buy off every pressure group in sight in the hope that the Liberals could get themselves past the next election—forecast a deficit of $1.7 billion; the outcome was $4.9 billion. It almost trebled.

I do not know whether that was actually a Treasury estimate because that Budget was hijacked by PM&C under the direction of Malcolm Fraser. However, it was certainly dishonest. I just do not believe that this was ever a Treasury estimate. The notorious section 10BA film concession was introduced as part of the 1982 Budget at an estimated cost of $2m a year. As I recall, that ultimately blew out to about $150m a year before the Labor Government cleaned it up. It also said that unemployment would peak at about 8 per cent when in fact it peaked at 10.5 per cent.

Moreover—and this is very important—if the public is to understand Federal Government budgeting, and if ongoing discipline is to be applied to it, they must understand that no government had published Forward Estimates of outlays until this Government was elected in 1983. It published Forward Estimates of outlays in the first year and has continued to do so ever since. Even if a subsequent government of a different party should want to revert to the dark, old days of Fraser, when everyone was kept in the dark because it made it easier to lie to them before the next election, it will not be able to avoid the degree of disclosure that is entailed in the publication of Forward Estimates.

Again just before the last election, in the very week of the poll, the then Fraser Government was still insisting that the impending Budget deficit for the following financial year—that is, 1983-84—was $6 billion. Of course, John Stone had told the then Government, in a minute which was subsequently published, that the impending deficit was in fact almost $10 billion, or 5 per cent of GDP—a record level.

Returning briefly to the Democrat amendment, it is incongruous to say the least—I will be as polite as I can—that the Democrats should be expressing concern about high levels of unemployment on the very same day that they gave notice of a motion the effect of which, if implemented, would be to close down about half of the timber industry. They cannot have it both ways. If they want to close down half of the timber industry, they cannot expect anybody to take them seriously when they pretend to be concerned about unemployment.

Even more startling was the denial by the Democrat leader that there is a linkage between economic growth and the level of employment. Has he never noticed that when economic growth turns negative, unemployment goes up? It does not always go down when economic growth turns positive, because a threshold has to be reached before unemployment goes down following economic growth going up. But whenever economic growth goes down, unemployment goes up. I would have thought that even the Democrats might have noticed that. It is truly mind-blowing that he should deny any linkage between economic growth and the level of employment.

Senator Chamarette did not speak on this matter today, but she delivered some pious notice of motion as well. Indeed, she rang me a couple of weeks ago to ask me what I thought about the Old Swan Brewery redevelopment in Perth, because she was asking all Western Australian politicians. I said, `What I believe the issue is now is whether decisions in Western Australia will be made by people elected to make decisions, or by ratbags like Bropho, Bill Ethell and you'—the `you', of course, referring to Senator Chamarette. If she seriously wants to run this line that it is a sacred site and therefore must not be violated in any way—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! Senator Walsh, I have been informed that you used a word that is unparliamentary and I ask you to withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: Then the people involved in the Peppermint Grove push who have been supporting Senator Chamarette on this issue for their own totally unworthy reasons will turn on her quick smart if they have to spend three or four hours a day trying to get into the central business district down Kings Park Road. The members of the Liberal Party will stop laughing now because it is their turn. It is also a bit hypocritical for the Liberal Party to talk about its concern for unemployment when it proposes to bring in its goods and services tax, or, more accurately, its value added tax. What would the Liberal Party do? There would be a major loosening of fiscal policy—major tax cuts, which will not be funded because there is a $6 billion hole in their arithmetic, and a 5 per cent boost in the CPI.
