TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the 1991-92 annual report of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The 1991-92 financial year was a very busy one for the Tribunal. As a result of a number of factors, not the least being the effects of the recession that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) claimed we had to have, the number of applications to the SSAT during 1991-92 was 33 per cent higher than in the previous year.

PARA.TAB: As is noted on page 1 of its annual report, the Tribunal managed to increase its output during this period by 19 per cent. It deserves to be congratulated for this fact, particularly when it is recognised that staff resources increased by less than 4 per cent during the financial year.

The SSAT also deserves the Senate's commendation for managing to improve the overall time for finalising appeals from 10.5 weeks in the previous year to 9.8 weeks in 1991-92. However, by the end of the 1991-92 financial year, it was becoming fairly obvious that the Appeal Tribunal's added workload was getting almost too much. The average time for the finalisation of cases had risen to 10.9 weeks. The number of cases not finalised at the end of the 1991-92 financial year was 81 per cent higher than in the previous year. The Tribunal was not able to maintain its 21-day standard for the provision of hearing applicants, with an average of 24.8 days between the date of appointment and the hearing to be held.
These figures indicate that the SSAT may have a resources problem. In its annual report, the Tribunal admits that this is a possibility when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we have only to look at the vast increase in workload this year to see that it is imperative to have a structure that is flexible enough to meet fluctuating demands.

Thankfully, in terms of its resources problem, there are two factors which the SSAT can look forward to in the coming year. First, a resources review is currently being undertaken at the direction of a steering committee chaired Professor Cheryl Saunders, which I am informed will develop a workload model that will be used to adjust the resources for the SSAT in light of the workload.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, in the 1992 Budget, the Government decided to provide compulsory reviews by the Department of Social Security authorised review officers. It is estimated that these additional reviews by the Department will result in more than 3,000 fewer appeals spread across all program areas to the SSAT each year. However, partially offsetting these factors will be the growing number of reviews by the SSAT of decisions taken by the Commonwealth Employment Service in relation to Newstart and the Jobsearch allowance.

As at 30 June 1992, 14 per cent of all the Tribunal's decisions related to applications for reviews of CES decisions. By 16 December 1992, CES related reviews had grown to nearly 18 per cent of the Tribunal's total workload, with nearly 60 per cent of all unemployment related reviews emanating from CES decisions. Not only are CES cases becoming more commonplace for the SSAT, but these cases are also adding to the Tribunal's workload as well as to the cost of cases. Each CES case involves two departments rather than one, which means that the Tribunal often must receive submissions from, and liaise with, both departments.

In answers provided to me during the recent Estimates hearings, and in chapter 7 of this annual report, the Tribunal recognised that it received many cases where the CES had cancelled a benefit due to a person failing to attend an interview. In an extremely high proportion of cases, these decisions to cancel were set aside because the Tribunal found that applicants had a reasonable excuse for not attending the interview in accordance with the legislation.

It is disturbing that, in such cases, the SSAT often found that the CES appeared to address only the issue of whether the person had attended the interview and not whether the person had a reasonable excuse for not attending, as is required by the legislation. In fact, in some cases, the Tribunal commented that the CES was not able to supply copies of correspondence or satisfactory evidence of postage, nor did it give details of a client's history. I find this matter disturbing because it shows how a government department's sloppy administration and mediocre interpretation of the law is obviously resulting in an even higher workload for the SSAT than it really ought to have, if what the SSAT is saying is correct.

In conclusion, I await the results of the review of the SSAT's resources and trust that these results will be provided to me on the conclusion of the review. I commend the Government for attempting to lighten the burden of cases coming before the SSAT by providing an additional review by authorised review officers in the Department of Social Security. But I urge the CES to look at the concerns that have been raised in this report.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Education, Employment and Training for inquiry:
The effect of the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974 on industrial relations in Australia, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (a)whether sections 45D and 45E are unduly harsh and restrictive when compared with International Labour Organisation conventions on freedom of association and the recently clarified right to free speech apparently implicit in Australia's constitution;

(b)what revisions to either the Trade Practices Act 1974 or the Industrial Relations Act 1988 should be made in order to clarify a worker's right to withdraw labour and under what conditions such withdrawal may or may not be pursued as a breach of contract; and
(c)whether sections 45D and 45E now provide adequate protection against secondary boycotts, in particular for small businesses, and the alternative means to provide such protection.

PARA.TAB: (2)That the committee report by the end of May 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of such a motion will be that the contentious matter, the matter which is notorious in the field of industrial relations—that is, the existence of section 45D and section 45E of the Trade Practices Act—be inquired into and examined by the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. The terms of reference are included on the Notice Paper. The effect of those is to give as broad as possible terms of reference for that Committee to examine:
The effect of the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act on industrial relations in Australia, with particular reference to:

PARA.TAB: (a)whether sections 45D and 45E are unduly harsh and restrictive when compared with International Labour Organisation conventions on freedom of association and the recently clarified right to free speech apparently implicit in Australia's Constitution;

SPEECH.PARA: This has not been noticed for some decades and that in itself is a good enough reason for that Committee to examine it. Part (b) of the terms of reference that I propose for this Committee states:

what revisions to either the Trade Practices Act 1974 or the Industrial Relations Act 1988 should be made in order to clarify a worker's right to withdraw labour and under what conditions such withdrawal may or may not be pursued as a breach of contract;
Part (c) of the terms of reference states:
whether sections 45D and 45E now provide adequate protection against secondary boycotts—
I come to the very particular reason for expressing it in this way, where the last part of the sentence reads:
in particular, for small businesses, and the alternative means to provide such protection.

The motion suggests that the Committee report by the end of May 1993. At first glance, such a date may appear to be so far into the future as to provide a buffer for the debate to reach a succinct and effective conclusion.

PARA.TAB: This is a matter which was first drawn to my personal and political attention soon after I became the Australian Democrats' spokesperson for industrial relations, just before Christmas 1991. At that stage the shuffling positions with regard to sections 45D and 45E had been going on for many years already. My contribution was to be part of the process which was examining a path for the transference of sections 45D and 45E away from the Trade Practices Act and into a more logical cocoon or collection within the industrial relations ambit. After months of negotiation and discussion between the various affected parties it proved to be too difficult a task for the Government to achieve with the package that was proposed just before Christmas last year.

With that experience, I suggest that there is more to this than meets the eye. It is not a superficial matter at all. It requires concerted and considerable discussion by a wide variety of groups, especially if my suggested terms of reference are to include consideration of what means of protection from secondary boycotts might be provided for small businesses. That is not an easy matter to resolve. I propose that this matter be given a comprehensive inquiry, not a superficial one by any means.

The attempts to deal with this matter have been several and unsuccessful to date. I believe that this matter should not be prolonged. I believe that it must be addressed. In discussions with members of trade unions, people who are practising employers and people who are practising individual small businesses—those aspects of our community who are most affected by these measures—I have received total agreement that this is a contentious part of the Trade Practices Act and also that it needs to be considered in depth and resolved.

Over the period that I have been involved with this I have found that of all the aspects of industrial relations practice—I do not say law because this is not part of industrial relations law—this particular little bundle of legislation has great mystique and little practical understanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is effective.

—Its effectiveness lies not in its particular legislative procedure, but rather in the threat of its application. Perhaps that threat of application has attached to it as much mystique as actuality. I think that it is time that mystique is removed, that we find out what we are dealing with and examine, as I propose in the terms of reference, whether sections 45D and 45E now provide adequate protection against secondary boycotts, in particular for small businesses, and whether there be alternative means to provide such protection.

PARA.TAB: There are notorious threatened applications of sections 45D and 45E which are directed not against industrial action but against other actions taken by other groups. We are familiar with the problematical threat of application of these sections to community groups such as Greenpeace, which, in conducting actions which can hardly be termed as industrial actions, have had the threat of running foul of this section. It is as much for that reason that the Democrats have as a priority in their policy that sections 45D and 45E should not be within the Trade Practices Act but rather that we should seek other means of addressing this particular problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support this motion. The reason came through very clearly in Senator Bell's final words. Having started off by saying that he was referring this matter to a committee so that it could be sorted out to decide what is the best way to protect innocent people against secondary boycotts, he then went on to say in his closing remarks that it was his view and the view of the Democrats that it should not be part of the Trade Practices Act. This was basically the intent of referring it to a committee. I do not know what the Government believes about this, but I think it would be very foolish to support it.

PARA.TAB: Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act are colloquially known as the Howard amendments to the Trade Practices Act. They were introduced in 1977 by then Minister, John Howard, for a very specific purpose. They were to protect innocent people against thuggery and standover by very powerful unions, almost in a mafia-like way, to threaten them to do something that some other union wished would occur. As a secondary boycott, it does not involve a direct dispute between an employer and his or her employees. It represents action done by a third party, specifically a union, which in the main would have no relationship whatsoever with the employer or his employees. In most cases I understand that the union which was threatening the secondary boycott did not have any members of its union in the organisation where there was a dispute.

The major effect of sections 45D and 45E is that they have been a deterrent. No-one would disagree with that because there have been very few instances where sections 45D and 45E have been implemented. I will refer to one later in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't resist it.
—I think Senator Bell is making the point that he can predict it, and so he should.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that when Mr Howard introduced these amendments the then President of the ACTU, Robert Hawke, approached him and was reported as having said that if Mr Howard persisted with them, there would be blood on the streets. That was the threat made by the then President of the ACTU to try to get Mr Howard to desist. He did not. Over 15 years it has served this country very well. There are many Labor people and many people involved in the trade unions, maybe even Senator McKiernan, who have had a long history of trade unions, who deep within their hearts would hope that sections 45D and 45E stay where they are. Senator McKiernan has to smile and shake his head, otherwise he would lose it. Perhaps the Government is committed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, we were discussing the motion moved by the Australian Democrats to refer sections 45D and 45E to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I had indicated that sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act are what are commonly called the Howard amendments. They were introduced to stop belligerent and militant trade unions from quite unfairly attacking small and medium sized organisations in a way equivalent to the sort of tactic that one would expect from the mafia rather than a civilised society. That legislation has now been in place for something like 15 years and has proved very effective, not because it has been used very often but simply because it acts as a deterrent to those who would otherwise engage in this quite obnoxious practice of secondary boycotts.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned earlier that I would give a little example because in the late 1970s I was somewhat involved in the shipments of coking coal into the European steel mills. Up until that time, the majority of our coking coal was sold into Asia, mainly into Japan, and it was thought wise to diversify, in the same way that the Japanese diversify their own supply sources. One of the difficulties we encountered back in the 1970s, because of OPEC pricing and so on, was an incredibly volatile shipping market. It was thought that a way around this—not as a method of making money, because there is no way to, or we could not, make money from large size vessels—was to predict the freight rate between Australia and Europe. In the absence of that predictability, the market that we were attempting to build up to diversify Australian resources could not survive. In the process, some eight ships were purchased, mainly second-hand, and they were generally named after lakes around the world. They were crewed by Spanish seamen, which is not unusual in the bulk trades because the Spanish have a long history going back hundreds of years—

TALK.START.PARA: —Christopher Columbus.

—Going back to Christopher Columbus, as Senator Cooney says. The Spanish have a tradition of being great seamen. However, the Seamen's Union of Australian decided that its members should man the ships. It must be understood that to bring back empty these large 100,000-tonne vessels, which go full from Australia to Europe, would be a quick way to go broke; therefore, some methods had to be worked out so they could be partly loaded for part of the way back from Europe. One method used was to pick up oil in the Middle East and bring it into places such as Port Stanvac in South Australia. When Lake Berryessa arrived at Port Stanvac it was basically arrested by the trade unions and impounded, where it sat idle for something like six months. The only way in which that situation could have been addressed—it was clearly a secondary boycott—was to invoke sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

PARA.TAB: I make it very clear that we had nothing whatsoever against the use of Australian seamen if they had been competitive with other ships around the world. If we are not competitive with other vessels, then there is no way in the world that we can continue to compete. That market into Europe where some 25 per cent or 30 per cent of our coking coal was being diversified would have come to nought. From the point of view of lost sales, not only would that have been a disaster for the Australian mining industry but also would have been a disaster for the viability of supply. So it was a very vital action which took place.

Sections 45D and 45E were invoked. This meant a fairly lengthy court case. Eventually, the seamen's union released the vessel which it had held illegally for six months. The net effect was that the company involved decided that it was not worth taking the risk of building up a merchant navy, which at that time everyone wanted, which we should have in Australia today and which, with the passage of time, with a bit of commonsense, we may have been able to maintain and expand.

I can recall very well the then president of the seamen's union, Elliott V. Elliott, making the remark in front of the judge hearing the case that the Lake Berryessa could actually stay in Port Stanvac until the bottom fell out of the ship. That was the sort of aggressive attitude of these people in the union who, in time, cut off their noses to spite their faces. With that sort of attitude, no-one I knew was brave enough to contemplate putting vessels onto the international market. That is a very sad reflection. The point is that it was only through sections 45D and 45E that there could have been some resolution; otherwise Mr Elliott V. Elliott would have been right and the ship would have stayed in port until the bottom fell out of the ship.

It is interesting to note that the action I initiated under section 45D never came to a conclusion. The point I made earlier was that, by the section being there, it acted as a deterrent in the future. Those who pursued this illegal action thought twice before doing so because of the potential damages that they themselves would incur.

This whole question of sections 45D and 45E has come up a number of times. Back in 1984, the Government, in an agreement with the unions on accord mark one, I presume it was in those days, agreed to get rid of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. It was debated in this place at great length. It is very interesting to note the comments of the Australian Democrats, led at that time by former Senator Chipp. Their spokesperson at that time was former Senator Jack Evans. He made the point, with all the toing and froing that goes on in this place, that the Democrats would not support the removal of sections 45D and 45E. In a debate that took place on 8 October 1984, Senator Jack Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we protect the interests not of the heavy pressure groups, but, for instance, the interests of small business people. . .

That is a very telling remark, because probably the most important aspect of section 45D is that it did protect the interests of small business people who could have been up until that stage singled out for belligerent attention. It is my belief that probably thousands of man hours have been saved in this country as a result of the existence of sections 45D and 45E. Former Senator Siddons, in a similar debate on 21 August 1985, made the remark:
In 1984 the Government introduced legislation to repeal sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act.
That was the commitment under the accord. He continued:
The Government was unable in 1984 to give the Democrats adequate guarantees for the protection of small business and innocent third parties.
The two key phrases are `small business people' and `innocent third parties'. He continued:
As a consequence the Democrats opposed the repeal of those two sections.

As I mentioned earlier, I believe that if the truth were known responsible people in the Labor Party were relieved when the Government could not meet the accord mark one promise. They know and I know and the business people are aware that those two pieces of vital legislation have helped not only our domestic industrial relations scene but also our reliability on world markets as a result of similar examples to that which I quoted in regard to the famous Lake Berryessa.

PARA.TAB: I also notice that in the motion on the reference to the Committee, the Australian Democrats talk about sections 45D and 45E being `unduly harsh and restrictive'. How on earth can these sections be unduly harsh and restrictive when they refer to something that is quite clearly illegal! It is not as if we are talking about disputes within an organisation between the employer and employee, some of which could be classified as legitimate. It is not as if we are talking about the right to strike. We are not. The right to strike comes when a person or a group of people in an organisation perceive an injustice and they talk about their right to withdraw their labour. That has nothing to do with this. This is no more or less than an attack by a group of unions who are trying to coerce an employer to capitulate because the direction in which that particular organisation is going does not happen to suit them.

I also notice here—and I find this quite fascinating—that they somehow link into this request, as part of their terms of reference, the `right to free speech apparently implicit in Australia's Constitution'. What an extraordinary statement! This refers to the ad ban Bill and the High Court decision where the Chief Justice of the High Court—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which the Democrats supported—the ad ban Bill.

—I am so pleased Senator Kemp interjected. This Labor Government would not have got through the ban on advertising without the support of the Australian Democrats. When the decision came down from the High Court we had the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) trying to rescue himself by saying, `What a victory for freedom of speech'. Now we have the Democrats, who supported the Government on this ban on free speech, coming here and saying, `Let us invoke this because of the High Court decision'.

PARA.TAB: The point I was making is that the Chief Justice of the High Court made it very clear that it was to do with parliamentary representation. I believe he went to great lengths to point out that one could not draw a long bow and say that this referred to some bill of rights or whatever. The judgment, in regard to all the judges, referred to political free speech, and to somehow lock into the High Court decision last week something to do with sections 45D and 45E is beyond belief.

The next term of reference, item (b), talks about `a worker's right to withdraw labour'. I think I touched on that by saying that sections 45D and 45E have no relevance whatsoever to that point. The next term of reference, item (c), talks about `whether sections 45D and 45E now provide adequate protection against secondary boycotts'. I suppose Senator Bell will clarify this, but I presume that the Democrats are saying that there was a time when sections 45D and 45E did provide adequate protection against secondary boycotts, in particular, for small business. He is now asking whether that still occurs. Yes, it still occurs.

Senator Bell mentioned in his opening remarks that this legislation was contentious and notorious in the field of industrial relations. I have not heard a peep about that in recent years. I have no doubt that if one talks to some of the left wing militant trade union leaders, they will raise it. The reason for their fury at the time about the Howard amendment to the trade practices legislation was that it reduced their power base; it reduced their ability to exercise power over others. In the main, those others that they were exercising the power over were the innocent people within an industrial dispute.

It is for these reasons that the Opposition will not support this reference. We believe it is mischievous. It could be that because the Democrats have lost a lot of support, mainly from the civil libertarians in society—who were appalled and shocked by their approach to the ban on electronic advertising of political matter—that they are now looking to pick up that little skerrick—I do not know how little or big it is—of support from the left wing trade union groups. Maybe the Democrats think that with this sort of approach they will pick up the support of people like John Halfpenny. I hate to use this term, because Senator Baume has used it so often in recent times, but let me say that pigs might fly. What will happen is that the Democrats will get exactly the same treatment from these union people at an election as they have always received in the past. In other words, they are being drawn into a matter which I believe has been to the great benefit of this country—most thinking people on all sides of politics will agree to that—and they are talking about reference to a committee.

A remark has been made by Senator Bell that the Committee should report by the end of May 1993. We in the Opposition are opposed to that because we strongly believe in the positive benefits that have accrued to this nation because of sections 45D and 45E. If the Government agrees with the Democrats and refers this matter to the Committee, it will be of great benefit to people on this side of politics because all those people who feel so strongly about the protection given to them as innocent third parties will, I am sure, be only too pleased to give evidence.

In conclusion, I reiterate that the Opposition opposes this reference for no other reason than that we believe it has been of great benefit to the Australian community. It has benefited not just employers—small, medium or large—but also those responsible elements in the trade union movement who did not engage and have never engaged in secondary boycotts. I think they were rather pleased with the fact that their more militant brothers—or perhaps I should call them comrades—did engage in that because in the process they helped give the union movement the bad name that it has today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the debate on Senator Bell's reference to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and to move an amendment which seeks to change the reporting date:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph 3, omit "the end of May 1993", substitute "the last sitting day in November 1992".

Having just heard what Senator Parer said, I think it may be obvious in one sense why I seek that amendment. I am not here to make life easy for either the Opposition or the Government. I honestly and openly state at the outset that I believe sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act should be repealed. Indeed, this morning I gave notice of my intention to introduce a private member's Bill to that effect in the next week of sitting.

PARA.TAB: I am not by any means alone in that view. The Australian Labor Party and the ACTU have such a policy, as has the Australian Democrats. In 1984, as Senator Parer has said, the ALP in government sought to repeal sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. I can do little better than quote Senator Button—today is probably an appropriate day to do that—who is now the Leader of the Government, from the debate on 5 October 1984 in which he made several very interesting points. Senator Button said on that occasion that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the section was so widely drawn that its main operation is in respect of industrial action which often has little, if any, effect on competition.
He further stated:
. . . it has become more a weapon directed at the industrial relations activities of trade unions under the guise of competition policy.
He went on to say:

The Fraser Government amended Section 45D in 1978 and 1980 to broaden its application against union activities. In addition, during 1980, Section 45E was introduced into the Trade Practices Act. Section 45D commonly operates to prohibit boycott situations arising from a refusal by employees to handle goods intended for a third party for the purpose of pressuring the third party to accede to certain demands.

Unlike the impression that Senator Parer has given, and may have wanted to give, these sections do not just operate against unions, they operate against persons—individuals—as well. We should bear that in mind in this debate.Senator Button also said in that debate in October 1984:

The Government is concerned about the possible effect of the remedies of penalties and damages which are available under the Trade Practices Act for contraventions of Sections 45D and 45E. These are potentially highly disruptive to Australia's industrial relations. Their application, where boycotts occur, is unlikely to lead to the effective or satisfactory resolution of the dispute.

This question, of course, is one that arises in the terms of reference put forward in Senator Bell's motion.Senator Button went on to note that practical experience had, even up until that time, shown that the remedies provided under the Trade Practices Act had not been effective in the way which is often claimed. He went on to say:

. . . when the evidence is examined, there is not much reason to conclude that the injunctive process has been particularly speedy or that using this legal remedy will help to resolve a dispute. In some cases, the issuing of an injunction under the Act has even led to a worsening of the dispute.
Senator Button also said:

I have argued to this stage that action under the Trade Practices Act in respect of secondary boycott disputes is neither the most appropriate course for resolution of the dispute nor necessarily a particularly quick or effective course of action.
So the debate went on.

PARA.TAB: From the same debate, possibly to the delight of those Opposition members present, I will also quote from the then Democrat spokesperson, Senator Jack Evans. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government should have a clear and concise message from the Australian Democrats. The repeal of sections 45D and 45E is not on as long as the Australian Democrats have the balance of power in this Parliament. . .

I regret to say that quite possibly the situation may be no different now from what it was when Senator Evans made that statement, in spite of the fact that since that time, and because of the work of many people within the Australian Democrats, myself included, there has been a change in the Democrat Party policy. That change occurred via ballot in the second half of 1991. The policy, republished in February 1992, reads:
Item 1: Support the repeal of Sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act.

On 31 July this year I resigned from the Australian Democrats and, to that point, no action on 45D and E had been taken by the Democrats.I did set myself an agenda for parliamentary work as an independent and sections 45D and E repeal was high on that agenda.

PARA.TAB: On 4 September I announced at a public sector seminar at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology my intention to give priority to drafting the introduction of a private member's Bill to repeal sections 45D and E during the October or November sittings of the Senate. I have had discussions with people in the Labor movement and begun preparation of that Bill. Knowing that the Democrat policy was in place, and with the ALP and the ACTU also having longstanding policies, I did believe that this initiative would get the issue off the backburner.

I have felt particularly strongly the need for action in this area as we have come closer in this country, and very much closer in my own State, to facing the New Zealand experience, one that we will probably face also federally.In taking this action I think it is important to stress that I believe the Australian working people will need every possible avenue that is open to them to protect their hard-won rights and protections as they move into the coalition's industrial relations wasteland, State by State and, as I said, probably, after the next election, federally.

Here I want to note that I lay it at the feet of the ALP in government that we face the possibility of a federal coalition government. The ALP in government has caved in to economic rationalism—to corporate government, with corporate unions and corporate business. It has brought us the recession and agonisingly high levels of unemployment and consequent justified anger in the community—anger which was vented in the Victorian State election a week and a half ago. There is no guarantee at all, despite obvious wishful thinking within Government, that such anger will not also be vented at the next federal election.

The scenario is that we may be given a coalition government by virtue of the ALP's failure to act as a Labor government in the truest sense. The least that this Labor Government could do is give the Labor movement what it promised, as Senator Parer outlined, back in 1984—repeal of sections 45D and E. Goodness knows, the Labor movement has had very little out of this Labor Government.Working Australians, as I said, need the best armoury they can have in preparation for the industrial relations wasteland.

I would add that I think not to do this on behalf of the ALP in government could possibly ensure that the ALP does lose the next election. I do not see how the Labor Party could expect working Australians to rally round in quite the way that they need to, to support the re-election of a Labor government in these circumstances. They will not stand by and meekly watch the ALP, with the Democrats, bury sections 45D and E repeal in a Senate committee to a date which goes beyond when we all know the next federal election will be. As for the ACTU, it has an obligation to put pressure on its Labor government to implement the policy of its rank and file, and not to just operate as a corporate executive in collusion with corporate government and corporate business. I do not believe that that executive rule will be tolerated by the union membership in these circumstances, and anger will be vented.

Of course, for those who are concerned about environmental policy, repeal of sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act also has a much greater sense of urgency and necessity as we move on towards the next election. There is some irony, I think, that the proposed burial of repeal, which I believe Senator Bell's motion in its present form represents, should be being debated in this chamber today, on the very day when the Democrats have effectively and justifiably sought to put a spotlight on the shortcomings of this Government in terms of its environmental promises at the 1990 election.I would have expected that those issues which are important to the environmental movement would have had higher priority.

Secondary boycotts can often be the only weapon that is available to protect the environment from unsustainable exploitation. I can hear now the bulldozers in the forests; I can see the sands being dug up; and I can see the endangered species disappearing before the onslaught of the ultimate economic rationalists who will make the Labor Party in government look like a bunch of pussycats. Unless this legislation is repealed, environmentalists—community people—will agonise over the question. I remind the Labor Party, the Opposition and, indeed, the Democrats, that when people have been polled on their issues of major concern, issues of the environment remain the highest priority as long term issues. People's memories do not fade and their concerns do not go away when it comes to the long term survival of the planet.

Secondary boycotts can be used to stop uranium exports, or to halt the importation of rainforest timber. They can also be used in the fight against environmentally damaging developments at local level by the people who are excluded from this sort of process. Not the unions, necessarily, I tell Senator Parer, but real people at their local level fighting for the future of the planet.

Tonight's debate and ultimate vote is not the end of this issue in the life of this Parliament. Though it is obvious that both the ALP Government and the Democrats will combine to ensure an end to this particular debate—in spite of the policies of their memberships—they are really saying, `We have a policy to repeal sections 45D and 45E but we want to spend the next seven months considering the whole issue'. By then, the next election will be over and it will be too late to act.

The Labor Party and the Democrats can give the lie to my view only by supporting my amendment to bring forth the reporting date to the end of November, a quick reference—and we all know that Senate committees are very good at quick references; we do them weekly—and one which would enable legislation implementing the policies of both those parties to be before this place and to be carried on the basis of the policies of those parties before we face the next election. As I said, I gave notice today of a Bill to effect repeal of sections 45D and 45E. The debate is alive and it will persist. In an ultimate vote on an unamended motion, I will oddly enough be voting with the Opposition in opposition to this motion, but for very different reasons, because I do not wish to officiate at the burial of all hope of repeal of sections 45D and 45E in the life of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Parer by opposing the motion to refer this matter to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I listened carefully to the remarks made by Senator Powell who highlighted a fact which I plan to also mention in my remarks, that is, how much the Australian Democrats have changed in their views on the proper relationship between trade unions and the law. Make no mistake, Mr Acting Deputy President, this reference to the Senate Standing Committee seeks to make fundamental changes to the law which currently governs the conduct of trade unions in our society.

PARA.TAB: Today the Morgan poll was released on Senate voting intentions. That poll showed that since the last election there has been a catastrophic fall in support for the Australian Democrats, from some 13 per cent at the last election to around 7 per cent today.

TALK.START.PARA: —And dropping.

—As my colleague Senator Knowles says, that support is dropping. Senator Knowles has probably been focusing on the figures in Western Australia which show an even worse trend than the overall national figures. If we ask ourselves why this fall in support has occurred—and it has occurred during the time that Senator Powell was Leader of the Australian Democrats, and now Senator Coulter is Leader—I suspect one of the reasons is that the former leadership of Don Chipp and then Senator Haines was not only more in touch with the views of their own supporters but also with the views of the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: The former leaders of the Australian Democrats—as mentioned by my colleague Senator Parer—were vehement supporters of sections 45D and 45E. In 1984, and again in 1987 before the election, the Labor Government attempted to repeal sections 45D and 45E. Make no mistake—I say this for those people who are listening to the debate this evening—these sections remain in the Trade Practices Act because of the Australian Democrats' support for the views of the Liberal National Parties that it was vital to retain those sections, in the legal arrangements governing the behaviour of trade unions, in an attempt to bring some order and some fairness and equity into the law.

Don Chipp perhaps reflected the older style approach of the Australian Democrats and the role they should play, which is in complete contrast to the current role that Senator Coulter and Senator Bell apparently see. I ask honourable senators to contrast this thought and the views of Don Chipp in 1983, as the Leader of the Australian Democrats, with the views we have heard this evening from Senator Bell and a former Leader, Senator Powell:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party and the trade union movement are by definition, inseparable. With these intractable vested interests, there's no way either of these parties can `bring Australia together' . . .
How right was Don Chipp, as time has shown. He went on:
. . . would you feel contented to have that power transferred to Bob Hawke, knowing the extravagances of the trade union movement could be ruthlessly impacted on him?

We have seen, in the relentless changes which have been made to industrial law during the period of the Hawke-Keating Government, a deliberate attempt to entrench the power and privilege of the trade union leadership—often at the expense of their members—in the law of this country. But until now they have not had the support in the Senate to remove sections 45D and 45E. We can recall that, under Senator Powell's leadership, Senator McLean went out of his way to establish very close links—in contrast to the previous policy of Senator Powell's Party and under her leadership—with the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: On 15 March 1991, a little over a year and a half ago, Senator McLean paid a much publicised visit to the ACTU. Senator McLean of the Australian Democrats said he would brief the executive on the Democrat's industrial relations policy and review legislation likely to come before the Parliament in the next two sessions. He indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: The appearance will cap off a strengthening of relations between the two which began after the ACTU Secretary, Mr Bill Kelty, and the President, Mr Martin Ferguson, took office.

That was a very important meeting, a quite historic meeting—historic in the sense that it perhaps symbolised more than others the complete about-turn in policy that the Australian Democrats had taken in relation to the trade union movement and the appropriate role of the law in governing the relations with trade unions. I suggest to Senator Powell that history will show that this was one of her fundamental mistakes. Another was her strong support for the ban on political advertising. The strong support she gave to that ban which served to inhibit the right of free speech is probably one of the reasons why, in the end, her colleagues did not wish to retain her as Leader of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that another fundamental mistake made by the Democrats under Senator Powell's leadership was their unthinking support for former Senator McLean's approach to remove sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act, which was out of touch not only with community thinking but also, as all the polls showed, with those people who in the previous election had supported the Australian Democrats. One of the opinion polls that was taken showed that some 70 per cent of Australian Democrat voters thought that governments should introduce stricter laws to regulate trade unions. But, under Senator Powell's leadership, her party ignored the wishes of Democrat voters and it encouraged Senator McLean to cosy up to the trade union movement. That is one of the reasons why some sections of small business that used to support her party, and which former Senator Chipp went out of his way to cultivate, decided that they would have no more to do with it.

I suggest that Senator Powell and Senator Bell ask themselves: who in the community demands the repeal of sections 45D and 45E? There is no up-swell of fury in the community about the use of 45D and 45E. In fact, I think a lot of people believe that those sections, to the extent they know about them, are a useful buttress to redress the balance of power among trade unions, employers and the general community.
Senator Powell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all. What happened was that Senator Powell, while she was the Leader of the Australian Democrats, ignored the express wishes of her own people, the people who voted for her, about the need not to unleash trade union bosses on the community and to recognise that the law in a number of areas was already too loose and needed to be tightened up. I suggest to Senator Powell that her support for increased trade union power—along with her support for banning political advertising—is one of the reasons she is no longer the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell, of course, has been faced with something of a dilemma. I have always listened very carefully to what Senator Bell has had to say about the IR area to see whether he had the courage to return the Australian Democrats to their traditional base. So I am disappointed that all that groundwork put in by Senator Powell and Senator McLean with the ACTU and trade union bosses has resulted in this motion coming before the Senate this evening.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you that Senator Bell and his party will pay a further price for threatening the rights of small business and for threatening the rights of ordinary workers who, above all, are the ones who suffer most from capricious trade union action. Senator Bell worries about secondary boycotts legislation in terms of the right to strike. It is interesting, and I think fair to say, that in his remarks he did not seem to worry about people and families who lost their income as a result of a strike in a plant unconnected with the work in their own plant; and he did not worry about the massive disruption which a strike in a certain key area could cause people in the wider community. He did not worry about those rights at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the motion.

—Clearly we can read the motion and we can read Senator Bell's intention in the motion. In a sense, as we come towards the election which Senator Powell quite rightly pointed out is now pending, she has put down on paper her intention to increase union power and to remove one of the restraints on the behaviour of trade union bosses; and Senator Bell has put down on paper his intention to remove one of the restraints on union power. We can now see where these people—the Australian Democrats, Senator Powell and the Independents—now stand on this issue, which I believe will be an important one in the next Federal election. If by some great mischance or misfortune the Keating Government were returned to office, there is no doubt that the removal of sections 45D and 45E would occur and that the trade union bosses, the Bill Keltys and Martin Fergusons of this world—who have never stood for office but still wish to run this country—would find themselves in possession of greatly enhanced power.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, at least we can say this: Senator Powell and Senator Bell and the Australian Democrats have nailed their colours to the mast on this important issue. Referring this matter to a committee will not end this debate. Let me tell Senator Bell and Senator Powell that this is only the start of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose one of the things that we have to face at some stage or other is whether we want to have serious debate in this chamber or a `sloganfest'—and oftentimes I fear the second description best suits. Unfortunately we have had a series of propositions and slogans put based not on any particular research or any particular inquiry but on the sort of inner instincts of the people who have given them.
—I gave practical examples.
—That is right. Senator Parer gave an example and I would have thought that that example was a very good one to put before the inquiry. If we look at the notice of motion—
—What's wrong with the courts, Barney?

—An interesting laugh has come from Senator Crane. He knows a lot about the industrial field. He opposes this motion and laughs at the suggestion there should be an inquiry. Let us have a look at the inquiry that he laughs at. Let us look at who the people on this Committee are, the people that Senator Crane—we have heard him and other people here will acknowledge this—laughs at. The Chairman of this Standing Committee is Senator Aulich. The members are Senator Calvert, who as a Liberal senator from Tasmania I think has universal respect in this chamber; Senator Foreman; Senator Sherry; Senator Sowada from the Australian Democrats; Senator Tierney—he laughs at Senator Tierney who is a Liberal senator—and Senator Zakharov. But who is the last member of this Committee whom I have not mentioned? It is Senator Crane. Senator Crane laughs at his own ability to conduct a fair inquiry.
—That seems reasonable to me.
—As Senator McMullan says, that seems reasonable to us. The motion before the chamber states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for inquiry.

Honourable senators have already heard me say who is on this particular Committee. It is a standing committee; it does not have to be got together from members of the Senate. It is there already. It is not, therefore, to be an expensive inquiry. It is a reasonable inquiry. It is reasonable because what we are going to do is ascertain facts on the way in which the particular sections of this Act have worked over the last few years and see, on the basis of those facts, what we ought to do.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that Senator Bell had not indicated in any way what his position is on these matters. What he has done is say, `Let's have an inquiry. Let's get the facts and ascertain what has happened'. Why should that be so violently opposed? What does he want to inquire into? He wants to inquire into:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974 on industrial relations in Australia, with particular reference to—
and I will go on in a moment to tell honourable senators what particular reference is to be made to.

PARA.TAB: Industrial relations will be one of the big issues for debate over the next months and coming up to the next election. Surely, it would be more than worthwhile to ascertain just how these sections have operated not only in the industrial community but in the general community over the years since they were passed in 1977. Paragraph (a) of the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)whether sections 45D and 45E are unduly harsh and restrictive compared with International Labour Organisation conventions on freedom of association and the recently clarified right to free speech apparently implicit in Australia's Constitution;

Why would anybody oppose us looking at whether or not we fulfil our obligations under the provisions of the International Labour Organisation? What is wrong with that? Why would anybody vote against a proposition that we look at our own backyard to see whether or not we comply with the conventions that we are party to?

PARA.TAB: The Opposition does not oppose unions. There is no suggestion of that. When Senator Crane gets up he does not oppose unions or the ILO. He is a person who has responsibilities in terms of international codes, including the International Labour Organisation. I trust that, being the man he is, he would want to comply with those conventions that his country has signed. The next paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: (b)what revisions to either the Trade Practices Act 1974 or the Industrial Relations Act 1988—
and honourable senators will note that two Acts are referred to here; not only the Trade Practices Act but also the Industrial Relations Act—
should be made in order to clarify a worker's right to withdraw labour and under what conditions such withdrawal may or may not be pursued as a breach of contract;

The Opposition does not even want to consider that as a proposition. This is one of the central features of any industrial relations system, no matter where it is, as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would know more than most in this chamber, having spent most of your life working in this area. PARA.TAB: The last proposition is:

SPEECH.PARA: (c)whether sections 45D and 45E now provide adequate protection against secondary boycotts, in particular for small businesses, and the alternative means to provide such protection.

I would have thought that people on this side—if they followed the Pavlovian approach taken by the other side—may have protested about this. We might say, `Look, why should 45D and 45E be kept on the statute books as inferred by proposition (c) if that is answered in a particular way?'.

PARA.TAB: At this stage I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment to the motion. I will move that the following part (d) be added to the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: (d)whether these sections are a satisfactory means of preventing and settling industrial disputes.

That seems us on this side to be an issue that ought to be discussed with the other matters; that is, whether these sections 45D and 45E are a satisfactory means of preventing and settling industrial disputes.

PARA.TAB: If my foreshadowed amendment is adopted and this matter goes before the Committee of which Senator Crane is a member, I hope that he will look at that issue fairly and apply to it the dictates of natural justice, which are that he comes to it with an unbiased mind and hears both sides of the matter. I hope he will do that and come out with the facts.
Part (2) of the motion reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee report by the end of May 1993.

Senator Powell, who made a very impressive speech, said we ought to have it by November. I do not think that meets the thrust of what I understand Senator Bell to be saying. He wanted a comprehensive—and I use that word in the absolute sense—investigation of how these sections are working, what their ramifications are and whether there are better alternatives to the present position, and he wanted the investigation to be carried out in a calm, dispassionate and fair way. Senator Powell was concerned that an election might take place. It may or may not but, in any event, the Government presently in office will be in office after May 1993. I hope that is of some comfort to Senator Powell.

PARA.TAB: We on this side support the motion moved by Senator Bell, with the additional paragraph that is set out in the amendment that I have foreshadowed. As I said at the start of this speech, it is very important that at some stage we in this chamber come down to considering issues on the facts and that we do not come here with predetermined minds.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—Senator Parer is a man who has laboured mightily for industry in Queensland and obviously his soul has been seared by the experiences he has had in the past. But, as a senator elected to represent all the people of Queensland and, indeed, with a responsibility to Australian citizens as a whole, it is his obligation—just as it is mine and every other senator's obligation in this chamber—to try to have a proper debate and not a debate based on throwaway lines and the prejudices that we all come to this chamber with. Our obligation is to sit down as an all-party committee—and apparently it is an all-party committee that the Opposition is afraid of—and come to some conclusions. There may well be differences on that Committee, but in those circumstances our obligation is to produce evidence across the board and across Australia about these matters so that that evidence can be brought here for the debate to go on.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane will follow me in this debate; Senator Parer has spoken already. But I would like them to explain to me at the next opportunity they have why they are concerned about an inquiry taking place about this matter. This inquiry will be staffed by people from both sides of the chamber and by a Democrat, who will come forward with their joint conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —A majority.
—Senator Parer says that there is a majority. He is prejudging his fellow senators.
—I know.

—The trouble with Senator Parer is that the more he speaks, the more he shows a mind that is predetermined. I could tell Senator Parer my predispositions about this. I think that to have sections 45D and 45E in the Trade Practices Act is a very clumsy and very wrong way of going about industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: The Trade Practices Act aims firstly at giving consumers protection and, secondly, at trying to free up the marketplace. I believe that sections 45D and 45E are quite inept and quite inappropriate in this situation. If those two sections were to be repealed, there may be other things to bring into the Industrial Relations Act, but for heaven's sake let us talk about the topic in a reasonable fashion. Let us talk about it as we should talk about it, given our responsibility to the electorate.

We will be in a much better position to talk about it in a rational and proper fashion, we will be in a much better position to discharge our duty to the Australian people who have elected us if we are properly informed, if we sit down in the calm of an all-party inquiry and if we get together some material on the subject. What is wrong with that?

As Senator Parer said, these two sections were passed in 1977—15 years ago. After 15 years surely it is reasonable to look at how the provisions operated, at whether the whole system can be improved, at whether there are better ways of going about the matter, given the fact that industrial relations have improved considerably over the last 10 years. Given all of that, surely it is reasonable to consider whether there are better ways of going about our relations in this field compared with the present position. I foreshadow the amendment and, subject to that being accepted, would support Senator Bell's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Powell's amendment. She outlined the arguments so well that there is little for me to add, but I want to support her remarks. Participatory democracy is extremely important to the Greens and we support ways of allowing people, at a local community level, to challenge decision making that has been taken out of their hands.

PARA.TAB: Senator Powell gave examples of the usefulness of secondary boycotts in relation to environmental issues. In relation to labour issues sections 45D and 45E are, as Senator Bell said in his motion, unduly harsh and restrictive when compared to International Labour Organisation conventions on the freedom of association and the right of free speech in the Australian Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that.
—Well, I believe that it is unduly harsh and restrictive and I support the wording in his motion.

PARA.TAB: In relation to environmental issues, the voluntary conservation movement needs all the help it can get if there is a coalition government after the next Federal election. The Australian Democrats pointed out earlier today how the ALP has failed the Green support it received at the last election with much concurrence in the comments from the Opposition benches. However, the Opposition gives ample evidence that it will be far worse. In that case I feel that the repeal of 45D and 45E is too important to be delayed for seven months.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the motion.

—The amendment is to the effect that it be done more quickly than in seven months' time. I feel the time set for committee consideration by Senator Bell's reference is a hollow and cynical exercise.
