SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in support of my colleagues in the debate on this motion and to make some comments of my own. I begin by dealing with the comments of Senator Chamarette. The first question I would like to ask her is who wrote her notes. She read them very assiduously. She did not know what she was talking about and she got herself in one hell of a muddle in the process.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette made some comments about environmental matters and environmental concerns. I thought I might just make one comment about that, although I do not see the relevance to this debate, in terms of the coalition's position on environmental matters. I would like to inform her, as I have informed other people in this chamber before, that in terms of practical environmental action the coalition believes in positive action. What are now known as soil conservation districts or Landcare districts were established in Western Australia after changes to the Western Australia Soil Conservation Act following a meeting between myself and the honourable Dick Old, who was the conservative Minister for Agriculture at that particular time. That model operates right across Australia. So Senator Chamarette can say what she likes about environmental concerns, and who cares—but that is fact, it is on the public record and I think she should know about it.

I think the tragedy of this reference is that, once again, we see an endeavour to link an industrial matter with what is essentially a restriction of trade matter. I doubt whether anybody on the other side of the chamber, the Democrats or the Independents, has actually read what the Trade Practices Act says. Section 45D of the Trade Practices Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this section, a person shall not, in concert with a second person, engage in conduct that hinders or prevents the supply of goods or services by a third person to a fourth person (not being an employer of the first-mentioned person). . .

Et cetera. For whatever reason, a number of people quite incorrectly have pulled this in and tried to make out that it is an industrial issue. It is not. It is a matter of movements of goods and services in the strictest sense of trade. Section 45E, which is also very important, states:

Subject to this section, a person who has been accustomed, or is under an obligation, to supply goods or services to, or to acquire goods or services from, a second person shall not make a contract or arrangement, or arrive at an understanding, with a third person (being an organization of employees, an officer of such an organization, or another person acting for or on behalf of such an organization or officer) if the proposed contract, arrangement or understanding contains a provision that. . .

Et cetera. It then goes on to outline what it is about. It is about the restriction of or the interference in the movement of goods and services. That is what the Trade Practices Act is about; it is what sections 45D and 45E are about. The fact that it has been abused in an industrial sense by a number of persons, a number of employers and a number of unions does not alter the fact that sections 45D and 45E are about the freedom of movement of goods and services within Australia and across its shores either by aircraft or by sea.

PARA.TAB: This part of the Trade Practices Act has been a very effective and cheap mechanism whereby in many cases, and I will touch on a couple of them in a moment or two, serious damage that could have been done to a particular business or persons—that is, a group of people or an individual—or to our position as a trading nation has been prevented. That is what section 45D and section 45E are about. This matter should not be confused with an industrial matter, although this motion does exactly that.

I am not going to cover all the points that my colleagues made in relation to the particular aspects of this motion, but some are worth re-emphasising. I particularly note some of Senator Cooney's comments, especially his particular reference to whether I would look at evidence that is before us in a fair and impartial manner if this motion is passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume you would.

—Senator Cooney questioned whether I would. I am surprised that he did that, because I believe that I have the capacity to look at things in a fair and impartial way and to make a judgment as to whether things that are put before us are right, wrong or fair. I am sure that the Acting Deputy President, who has sat with me on some committee hearings, would attest to that fact. Nonetheless, I am not here to talk about myself.

PARA.TAB: The main part of the motion before us is cut up into parts (a), (b) and (c). Firstly, in my time in this Parliament, which has been just over two years, this is the first time, certainly on a committee on which I have served, that a reference from a committee member has not been brought to the committee before it came to this chamber for some discussion. From that point of view, I say to Senator Bell that I am very disappointed and alarmed about that.

Had this reference come before the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, there could have been an opportunity to clarify it, make it better or amend it with the wisdom of all Committee members around. I do not know whether with other committees it is the practice that notices of motion in terms of references to committees go to the committees concerned or come to this place. Obviously, there is no reason why they cannot come here directly. As a matter of practice, one would get better resolutions before the Senate if the committee had the opportunity to examine them in the first place.

The first part of the motion, which is broken into parts (a), (b), and (c), goes straight to the point of section 45D and section 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974. It then goes on to talk about industrial relations in Australia. As I have already said, section 45D and section 45E are about restrictions of trade. In my view, if this motion is passed and amended by Senator Powell's amendment or Senator Cooney's amendment, I am quite prepared to look at the various aspects of it. As I said, this issue is about trade; it should not be confused with industrial relations.

Part (a), which tries to tie section 45D and section 45E to the High Court decision with regard to free speech, is the most extraordinary part of the motion. I cannot in my wildest dreams ascertain how one can relate the restriction of the movement of goods and services to the right of an individual to free speech. In fact, if the two were to be tied together, I would have thought that the right to freedom of movement of those goods and services would go closer to free speech than what is suggested in part (a) of this motion, where it talks about section 45D and section 45E being unduly harsh and restrictive when compared with the International Labour Organisation conventions on freedom of association.

Senator Cooney also mentioned ILO conventions and where I stood in terms of Australia's signatory to those. While Australia remains a signatory to a particular convention, I believe that we should respect that signature. I also give notice that that does not stop Australia, as a nation, examining some of these conventions and treaties that we have signed over the years. I do not believe at this time that some of those are in the best interests of Australia for a variety of reasons, which I will not go into tonight.

Part (b) of the motion, which clarifies a worker's right to withdraw labour and states under what conditions such withdrawal may or may not be pursued, raises a very interesting point. That is what section 45D and section 45E of the Trade Practices Act in one sense, although it is a trade matter, are all about; that is, it is the right of an individual to trade his goods or services without interference by other people, particularly those who exist outside a direct relationship with the people doing the trading. I believe that section 45D and section 45E have clarified this position very succinctly.

I relate to what was part of the embryo of section 45D and section 45E. I am not going to claim here that it was the sole issue, because I know it was not, but it was very important in terms of the necessity for section 45D and section 45E to be placed in the Trade Practices Act. There was no section 45D and section 45E in the Trade Practices Act in 1974 for protection against people who interfered, be it individually, collectively or otherwise and from whatever spectrum, with the movement of goods and services.

At that time, the Western Australian Farmers Federation, which was then known as the Farmers Union—I was a member of the executive—decided to take legal action against the bans that were applied to the movement of wheat in Chilean and Indonesian flagships. Our only effective recourse in law to the bans that were placed on that, which put at risk a very significant amount of Western Australian wheat trade, not to mention wheat from other States, was the Crimes Act. We were successful in using the Crimes Act in that case to have those bans lifted from those ships.

There were a number of problems with using the Crimes Act. The two principal ones were that, firstly, one had to go through the process of proving prima facie evidence, which meant it was then handed over to the State to run one's particular case. It was slow, cumbersome and expensive. The other thing which I did not like about being forced to use the Crimes Act was that one of the penalties involved with it was a mandatory gaol sentence. I emphasise that point. Either section 30 or section 31 was the part of the Crimes Act which dealt with restrictions on trade. Even though at that time I and other members of the executive that I served on were determined to go through with that measure, we did not sit comfortably with the fact that the people involved in creating the bans on the loading of those ships could end up in gaol.

When sections 45D and 45E were introduced not only were the injunctive powers much quicker but also they were much cheaper, and the penalties—this may not be exactly the correct way to put it—far more befitted the crime than what existed and still exists in the Crimes Act today. That is part of the reason that section 45D came into being. Paragraph (c) of the terms of reference states:

SPEECH.PARA: whether sections 45D and 45E now provide adequate protection against secondary boycotts, in particular for small businesses, and the alternative means to provide such protection.

That is a very interesting clause because one would have thought that if the Democrats, through Senator Robert Bell, thought that they had a better way of overcoming the alleged problems that sections 45D and 45E have in terms of restrictions on trade in Australia, they would have put it on the table. It is not on the table. I believe that this is a political manoeuvre to try to create a situation which might well occur where they think they can pick up a few disenchanted Labor Party votes in the lead-up to the next election. I think that is what the ploy of this little exercise is about.

PARA.TAB: I turn further to what is in the terms of reference and another reason why I could not support them. I am talking about the reference to the Industrial Relations Act 1988. In the 2 1/2 years that I have been here I have sat on a number of committees. In a vast majority of cases it was expected that the terms of reference be precise and be designed to look at a particular aspect of a problem, deal with that and then get on with the next aspect of the terms of reference relating to that particular inquiry.

Paragraph (b) mentions the Industrial Relations Act 1988. I seriously ask the Democrats, the Independents and the Government whether they are really serious about us conducting an inquiry with the scope which exists in the Industrial Relations Act 1988. Are they suggesting that we look into certified agreements? Are they suggesting that we look into the contractors legislation? Are they suggesting that we look into all aspects of industrial relations law which exists in Australia at this time? I would suggest that these terms of reference say precisely that. That is what I interpret them to say, although there is an emphasis on sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

If we start looking at how broad and how wide the International Labour Organisation conventions that Australia is a signatory to are I would have thought it would be far better if we were going to look at a particular concern of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act that we should be looking at the Trade Practices Act. Sections 45D and 45E are about restrictions of trade and the movement of goods and services. It is spelt out very clearly in the Act.

There are a couple of other points that I would like to make about this particular reference relating to things that have been said here tonight. I particularly refer to Senator Powell's remarks about having the Committee report by the end of November or thereabouts. Senator Powell may have changed her stripes as far as being a Democrat is concerned but she has not changed her stripes as far as using the guillotine is concerned. If we are going to have an inquiry into this matter and look at some of the things that I have mentioned in terms of the width and breadth of it, it is absolutely ludicrous to suggest that the Committee could report in any comprehensive or responsible manner between now and the end of November.

It is also interesting to note that the repeal of sections 45D and 45E is the policy of the ACTU, the policy of the Government and the policy of the Democrats. Senator Powell made reference to Senator Button and made it quite clear that her position was for repeal of section 45D and 45E as was that of Senator Chamarette.

If this reference were to go to the Committee—despite what Senator Cooney said about giving it a fair and equitable hearing, we already have a policy position adopted by all the main players in the game—there is no way that it would get a fair and equitable hearing and come to a just conclusion. For those and other reasons, I nor my colleagues can support this particular reference.

I would like to close with some brief comments relating to the application of sections 45D and 45E and the number of situations which have been brought to a head or short-circuited because of sections 45D and 45E. It has not so much related to the use of sections 45D and 45E in the strict legal sense. I can relate to both sides of the equation, not just employees but also employers. There are a number of famous cases where employers colluded with individuals and unions to place a boycott on the movement of goods and services. Once two or three cases had gone through the law courts all it took was a phone call to say to the individuals involved, whether it be the employee, the employer, the union or the organisation, `If you don't restrain yourself from that particular activity we will have no option but to take action under sections 45D or 45E of the Trade Practices Act'. For that reason, if for no other, it has been a very effective measure to stop the interference with the movement of goods and services in this country and it has also been very cheap. It has not run into the thousands of dollars that has been spent on legal fees when dealing with particular interferences in goods and services and other legal cases.

I have touched on a number of things relating to this reference before us tonight. The two most compelling reasons why this reference should not go ahead are, firstly, it is not confined to dealing with the alleged problems which exist in the movement of goods and services under the Trade Practices Act. It totally opens up the Industrial Relations Act 1988. Secondly, the situation which exists in terms of the people who will be sitting down in judgment, as Senator Powell has already explained to us, all have very strong strict policy positions and it would require a decision of their parties or the Australian Council of Trade Unions to change their position and we all know that that is not going to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a very short statement to correct an impression that Senator Crane may have gained from my speech. Senator Crane said that I was suggesting that he would bring a biased and prejudged mind to the inquiry. In fact, the point I was making was the other way. I said that, given the fact that he and other members of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training had unbiased minds and had the ability to bring clear minds to the inquiry, it ought to go ahead on that basis.

—in reply—I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate on my motion to refer a matter to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. It certainly ranged far and wide. As I said in my opening remarks, the matter has some history. We have been reminded of some parts of that 15 years of history.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer told us in the debate how wonderful sections 45D and 45E have been and of their effect on the Australian industrial scene during those 15 years. He then gave us some of the political history involved and quoted some past Australian Democrat senators. Senator Parer quoted former Senator Jack Evans as saying that these sections were about protecting the interests of small business people. Senator Parer then quoted former Senator Siddons as saying that the Government had been unable to give the Australian Democrats sufficient guarantees for the protection of small business and innocent third parties and that, therefore, the Australian Democrats at that time had not been supportive of moves to repeal the two sections.

I would have thought that the explanation of the concerns which led Senator Parer to seek to put and then quote previous Democrat positions have been addressed by the motion that I have moved. It is a question of whether—it is quite implicit in paragraph (c) of the motion—sections 45D and 45E now provide adequate protection. That of course is 15 years after the implementation of the original legislation. That is 15 years worth of development in industrial relations practice.

We are now in a position where enterprise bargaining takes place. In that period of time—and the results are irrefutable—we have developed a consultative and cooperative attitude towards workplace negotiation rather than the confrontationalist attitude that is inherent in the adversarial injunctive method summarised and exemplified by sections 45D and 45E.

That development begs the question whether these sections are suitable now. That is the question being asked by this motion. No answer is proposed by me or its supporters either by implication or directly. However, the question is asked whether these sections are adequate now.

Senator Powell suggested a couple of times that this motion served the function of burying the repeal of sections 45D and 45E in a committee. I suggest that is not so. I made it clear in my earlier remarks that those affected by this matter can hardly afford to ignore their considerable responsibility to fully present their case to the Committee. That is a responsibility which all parties affected by this legislation must recognise. It is a nonsense to suggest that they would shy away from putting that case. That case is public property and is in the forum of the election debate that will surely occur. That election debate will be running at the precise time that these positions will be being fully presented and, I suggest, will be anything but buried. I suggest that in fact it will be exposed to the fullest extent. To ignore the opportunity to expose this argument to the fullest extent possible will be at the peril of those groups, individuals and bodies that are at all affected by this issue. This Committee will be a vehicle for providing that opportunity.

The information gleaned by this committee process will be available and there for all to see. The recommendations of the Committee will be there for all to see and available to whichever party claims government after June 1993.

The next contribution came from Senator Kemp, who spent a good deal of time making sure that we understood some latest poll results. I say in passing that I can readily demonstrate that this action which I am taking—it has come to fruition today—is not motivated by any attention I have paid to polling. I have a thoroughly cynical attitude to polling. That is because the poll immediately prior to my election predicted that I would receive about one-seventh of the primary votes that I actually received. If at the next election I receive a similar increment over the present poll in Tasmania, I could bring in more Australian Democrat senators than there would ever be of Labor and Liberal senators from Tasmania combined. I recognise the ridiculousness of such a position. Senator Watson is alarmed by it—and so am I. I am therefore most cynical of polling.

Senator Kemp knows little about the exigencies of Tasmanian voting habits. I recognise and respect the balloted and established policy of our Party, and that is what I am required to put forward. We in our Party do not have the option of hopping around in response to an opinion poll or the hottest pressure group of the month. As honourable senators have been reminded several times during this debate, Democrat policy is clear on this matter and it is that which has motivated this matter being brought to a head. As a matter of fact, it was before Christmas 1991 that we were first attracted to the prospect of being able to do something about section 45D. It was in fact a part of the proposed industrial relations amendment package which was being negotiated at that time. At that moment I thought that there may have been offered by the Government a path of dealing more sensibly with these aspects of the legislation. That package was withdrawn—not followed through—by the Government.

In the interim we have seen some other amendments to the Industrial Relations Act. We have seen the successful introduction of those amendments without the doom and gloom which had been predicted by pressure groups at the time. Subsequently, I know—and Senator Watson may also know this—that recent figures on the building approvals that have been passed in southern Tasmania at least have shown a remarkable improvement over the previous month. I think the increase is of the order of 7 per cent. That is a trend which is also reflected in the ACT where there has been somewhat of a boom in housing over the past few months. That is in contradiction of the predictions of those who lobbied against the Industrial Relations Act. That is by the by. We have these dire predictions after the passage of some legislation.

We have reached the stage where we could see that the Government was not proposing any other additional amendments to industrial relations legislation. We could also see the opportunity for any examination of this slipping past, thus reducing the opportunity for reference or even consideration of this aspect of our industrial relations practice.

In his contribution to the debate, Senator Cooney demonstrated the reasonableness of this inquiry and suggested, lo and behold, that the inquiry would elicit facts. That is a matter which seemed to escape previous contributors to the debate. Senator Cooney then went on to consider reasons why the coalition might not want to expose its policy on this matter to a committee of inquiry. He searched for reasons why the coalition might not want to refer the matter for impartial inquiry. He searched but could not find any reasons for that refusal. In fact, we have had some reasons promoted by the coalition, but I suggest that they do not stand up to scrutiny. I suggest that the reasons are hollow because the inquiry simply seeks to establish facts, as Senator Cooney suggested, which can lead to a balanced consideration of this matter.

Senator Chamarette contributed a few words in support of the amendment by Senator Powell to introduce a reporting date in November. I was not convinced. In fact, Senator Chamarette did not mention in her contribution—perhaps she was not required to mention it, but I thought it would have come into the discussion at some stage—the actual work of the Committee. I may be criticised for referring this matter to this Committee, but search as I might, I could not find the opportunity for other committees to take on this matter, or its relevance to any other committees.

We are told in the Notice Paper that the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training is involved in at least two inquiries at the moment: one into the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act and another into the implications of sustained high levels of unemployment among young people. Both seem to me to have some degree of importance and should not be overshadowed by a quick, slick inquiry which could only be superficial in the time allowed. Also, they could impinge on that inquiry.

Perhaps I could have suggested and even made a case to refer the matter to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs chaired by Senator Cooney, as he is such a reasonable sort of fellow. We are told again in the Notice Paper that the five inquiries being run concurrently by that Committee are perhaps just a little overwhelming.

I would also remind honourable senators that at the moment the Senate has some 115 Bills remaining for consideration in the 20 sitting days until Christmas. In the time since the Senate was presented with the list of 132 Bills in early September, we have managed to pass 17. I was never confident of a reporting date which required any degree of haste from honourable senators in their consideration. I use the words of another honourable senator who contributed to the debate when I say that haste would remove the opportunity to provide a comprehensive and responsible reaction to this reference.

I usually listen carefully to and am entertained by what Senator Crane says. Senator Crane was meticulous in his presentation. He said that sections 45D and 45E were about freedom of movement of goods and services and thus belonged within the Trade Practices Act. I do not dispute that that is Senator Crane's opinion. There are perhaps thousands of Australians who consider that is not correct, but that is not what I would contend now, either for or against. TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that some four months ago, when we were discussing the Development Allowance Authority Bill, I raised in this chamber the fact that some of the measures before us then had been designed to lead Australia out of recession but time and time again the proposals were too narrow and too restrictive—and I referred in particular to the infrastructure proposals and the lack of use of limited partnerships in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) which was being discussed at that time.

PARA.TAB: But tonight I rise to comment on the Bill before us, the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill, which certainly acknowledges some of the limitations that we drew attention to some four months ago. The Government states that the primary purpose of the Bill is to increase the flexibility of the principal Act, otherwise known as the Development Authority Allowance Act, so that a more consistent approach is available for the various types of prospective applicants for the development allowance.

The Development Allowance Authority was announced as one of the measures of the One Nation statement and was established as recently as May of this year to assess the eligibility of large projects for the development allowance. Since then, according to the Government, it has become clear that amendments are desirable. Consequently, this Bill will allow for applicants for the development allowance to elect to aggregate two or more joint venture projects or specified projects and bring expenditure incurred in the long term lease of certain new units of a plan within the ambit of the original legislation.

When the original legislation was introduced into the Parliament three months ago, I indicated that there were certain problems associated with the set of criteria determining which were the companies which could avail themselves of this deduction—a deduction which is equal to 10 per cent of the eligible plant expenditure in the first year that plant is installed ready for use. I noticed specifically that the Government's proposed development allowance could discriminate against small projects, that is projects with a capital cost of less than $50m. I stated that this $50m threshold was arbitrary and distorting and encouraged vertical integration which may or may not have been the most efficient production structure.

With pleasure, I note that the amendments proposed by this Bill to the original Development Allowance Authority Act include some of the changes I noted that were then necessary. Two new types of schemes are introduced with this legislation. They are described as an `individual pilot scheme' and a `joint venture project scheme'. These schemes will allow projects involving new productive facilities to be added to projects which expand existing productive facilities and, therefore, will qualify for the allowance by meeting the $50m threshold test. Further flexibility in meeting the $50m threshold can be obtained by combining purchases and leased assets in a project. A mechanism is also introduced whereby a lessor can claim the development allowance benefit by way of a pre-qualifying certificate that has been issued by the Development Allowance Authority to the lessee. There is also now going to be a new vertical integration test and a number of other consequential amendments to the original legislation.

Therefore, the amendments contained in this Bill will allow the aggregation of new productive facilities with other projects consisting of the expansion, upgrading or improvement of existing facilities where the new and existing productive facilities are vertically integrated. At the time of the introduction of the original legislation, I further stated that this development allowance was nothing more than a band-aid solution which would only provide a small drop in the ocean of reforms that were needed to put this country back on its feet. This allowance is only expected to provide $40m in 1993-94 and $70m in 1995-96—a rather modest allowance. For example, Mr Colin Myers, a spokesman from MIM Ltd, one of Queensland's largest companies, said that it was not the sort of benefit that would make the difference between projects commencing or not. The very modest benefit that such an allowance would provide to industry must be contrasted with the coalition's Fightback program which provides $20 billion in tax relief for business; this $20 billion would encourage investment and create real jobs.

As this chamber has heard time and time again, this country does need major tax reforms if it is to become a viable economic nation once again. If this Government were serious about investment in Australia, it would abolish payroll tax, wholesale sales tax, fuel excise tax and cut personal income tax. However, though I welcome the amendments, the proposals are still too restrictive, in particular the $50m threshold. This threshold will deliberately cut out highly efficient and productive capital projects which just happen to fall below the $50m threshold. Therefore, although these amendments will make the development allowance more attractive, the coalition will continue to doubt the benefit of this Bill and the concept that it espouses for the same fundamental reasons it had when it opposed the original legislation. Not only does it discriminate against projects with a capital cost of less than $50m, it also does not make it available for investment in plant and equipment in all the areas of the economy.

The original legislation specifically excluded projects from the following areas: retailing, wholesaling, office accommodation, non-tourist accommodation, business or financial services, residential real estate, and print or electronic media. The legislation is specifically confined to factories, mines, quarrying, wharves and other port facilities, hotels, pipelines, and transport facilities. Further, a test of absence of structural assistance or protection is also applied so as to exclude projects predominantly in textile, clothing and footwear; passenger motor vehicle or parts; dairy products; tobacco; and raw and refining sugar industries. The exclusion in the latter does not apply where the Development Allowance Authority is satisfied that the projects will receive industry specific assistance of 10 per cent or less.

Another one of the arbitrary qualifying criteria is that projects must meet the competitiveness test. Included in this test is the provision that the projects must espouse industrial relations agreements or arrangements which promote the achievement of world best practice as well as projects themselves needing to be the `world best' in economic terms and efficiency. How the Government intends to determine this `world best' criteria I believe is difficult to understand as the criteria for the competitiveness test are given scant attention in the explanatory memorandum in the original legislation, although they are mentioned in clauses of the legislation. This suggests that the Government could be giving scant attention to these criteria when it comes to interpreting the legislation.

The question that arises is with regard to the phrase `world best practice'. What is the sense behind setting up a scheme of special assistance when the recipients are firms that already are identified as having little or existing assistance but have in place world best management and industrial relations arrangements? Obviously, if firms have world best arrangements in place, they would not require any additional assistance from taxpayers to compete in the international marketplace. However, this competitiveness test will not apply to projects commenced prior to 31 December. This calls into question just how serious the Government is about applying the competitiveness test.

As my colleague in the other place Mr Bruce Scott, the honourable member for Maranoa, has pointed out, this waiving of the competitiveness test has raised serious contentions within industry. For example, Mr Peter Wade, the Director of North Broken Hill Peko, has argued that this exemption has defeated the whole purpose of the legislation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why should we have one set of rules for a project which starts this year and another for the next?
Mr Wade said that world best industrial practice in the mining industry may be to have no union rather than single union coverage, as is proposed by the Government's guidelines for the allowance.
He continues:
I do not mean to be facetious about it but it is almost an impossible series of situations to measure up to.

These comments come from one of the nation's major investors. This company wants to invest in this nation, but to do so it requires, as do all other business leaders in this country, long term, reliable policies, and not ad hoc, one-off government proposals.

PARA.TAB: The Development Allowance Authority Act and the amendments proposed by this Bill before us tonight are a deliberate attempt by this Government to pick the winners and give selective industry assistance. In this instance the Government seems to have completely ignored the Industry Commission's detailed criticism of selective industry assistance which it made in its 1989-90 annual report. There is a chapter in that report entitled `Strategic Trade Theory and the East Asian Experience' which demonstrates exactly why the approach taken by this original legislation is precisely the wrong approach. The Industry Commission concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Economic success in Japan and the dynamic Asian economies cannot be closely associated with strategic Government intervention. . .
Industry specific assistance far from being a prerequisite for success is likely to be harmful especially if it is extensive and maintained over long periods.

The way ahead for Australia is not down the path of selective industry assistance. The way ahead lies in relieving industry, and Australians more generally, of the burden of government and its operations at all levels.

PARA.TAB: It should not be within the capacity of government to identify investments, businesses or industries that are likely to be successful in the future. The taxpayer should not be paying for failed businesses. The responsibility for this lies with the shareholders because they can make the decision whether or not to invest and will either reap the rewards or suffer the consequences.

The original criteria of the legislation passed in this chamber only three to four months ago were too restrictive. Companies have not been applying for this allowance. The Government could not advertise that capital investment was occurring. Therefore, the only reason the Opposition can see why the Government is proposing these amendments before us today is that, with the relaxation of the criteria, one or two capital projects will register with the DAA for this particular allowance. The Government can then state that the economy is recovering and say, `Look at the investment that is occurring'.

In summary, the coalition believes that this current Bill is clearly a blatant attempt by the Government in a pre-election environment to maximise the number of companies that will qualify, at least on paper, for assistance. When this happens the Government can then state that it is getting investments back on track. Since this Bill is an attempt to acknowledge certain of the defects in the parent legislation—although as I have explained, it is quite inadequate—the Liberal-National coalition will not be opposing this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1992 which seeks to amend the original legislation, the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992. This piece of legislation seeks to reduce the restrictions which govern the eligibility of a particular project to qualify for the development allowance.

PARA.TAB: The development allowance is a tax concession which was announced in the One Nation statement and is an investment allowance at a rate of 10 per cent for projects registered before 31 December 1992 and with a value greater than $50m. It was a measure specifically designed to stimulate investment to assist in returning decent levels of economic growth. However, we would agree with Senator Watson that it is a fairly cynical election ploy to fast track investment and development to create jobs in the lead-up to an election.

I note that there are numerous amendments to various sections and I am concerned that there has been a need for such major surgery on this legislation just four months after the principal Act was put in place. Indeed, I note that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has requested an explanation from the Minister as to why these amendments were required so soon after the passage of the principal Act. The need for these amendments highlights the fact that this concession was conceived and introduced on the run as part of the Government's political agenda and, hence, was not properly thought through.

It is therefore obvious that this amending Bill is in response to the valid criticisms levelled against the principal Act by wide sections of industry. I find it hard to believe that the Government did not perceive a necessity to allow applicants for the development allowance to elect to aggregate two or more joint venture projects or specified projects and to bring expenditure incurred in the long term lease of certain new units of plant within the ambit of the original Act.

I hesitate to use the term `sloppy legislation' in this place, but this would appear to be the case. It is obvious that the original legislation has not been able to attract the high level of investment that the Government had envisaged. The Opposition opposed the original legislation on the basis that it was too restrictive and that it was only available to large projects and was too interventionist. It is clear that this criticism of its being applicable only to large projects has in fact been vindicated by the Opposition and the necessity for this particular amending Bill. I would suggest to the Government that perhaps we might see even further amendments to the development allowance which might bring down the threshold of projects that are eligible for the concession.

How can the Opposition oppose restricting industry assistance to those initiatives which involve international best practice as is the case with the development allowance? At the very time when we are facing the imperative of becoming more efficient or perishing, it is essential that we as legislators insist that new projects which obtain special concessions be as competitive as possible.

However, the Democrats see no reason not to support this legislation. We have previously criticised the principal Act in that it does not make the allowance available for projects within industries whose nominal and effective rate of assistance is greater than 10 per cent. This badly impacts on the textile, clothing and footwear industries and on the passenger motor vehicle industry. We voiced that criticism when this legislation came before us last time, and we voice it now.

We would also agree with Senator Watson's assertion that the original Bill discriminated against small projects and against ventures with a low development threshold. We believe that in particular this discriminates against new developing high-tech industries. The exclusion of any sector which is protected is a short-sighted and flawed notion and will act against the longer term restructuring that these industries must undergo. Indeed, it is these very industries which need high levels of investment in new plant and equipment in order to survive into the 1990s.

The Government's and Opposition's determination to butcher these vital industries—industries which employ thousands of Australians—through a blind commitment to the almost total abolition of tariffs is quite beyond reason. These industries cannot compete against low wage countries without far superior productivity and this can only occur through massive new investment in plant and equipment.

Given the bleak outlook for domestic production, it is little wonder that there is a dearth of investment which is essential to these industries' survival. As such, the development allowance should be available for investments which meet the best practice criteria, irrespective of the state of protection, especially since there may be no protection at all during the lifetime of the facility.

I am led to believe that the Development Allowance Authority is, as we speak, receiving applications on the assumption that these proposed amendments will become law. The Government appears to be eager to be viewed favourably by a wider section of industry than that covered by the original legislation.

We did attempt to get some figures from the Development Allowance Authority to see exactly how the original legislation has been performing. We were unable to obtain those statistics. However, I do believe that Senator McMullan has some figures here and will present them later on in the debate. We will certainly be very interested to hear what he has to say. I wish that we had had an opportunity to obtain that information before this legislation came before the Parliament.

I put it to honourable senators that the original legislation has not had the anticipated effect of revitalising business investment. It is a white elephant and the Government is now frantically legislating amendments in an attempt to encourage business to invest and soak up some of the mass of unemployed

SPEECH.PARA: people who are presently floating forlornly through CES offices with no hope of a job in the immediate future.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, the legislation has failed in its aim of attracting major investment. This is why I have circulated the second reading amendment which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . , but the Senate condemns the Government for the monumental failure of the development allowance to attract major investment, a failure which has been conclusively demonstrated by the need to amend this legislation within only 4 months of having first established the Allowance.

PARA.TAB: The proposals before us seek to improve access to the existing development allowance without altering the basic structure. For example, as I said, the $50m threshold will remain although improvements in and upgrading of existing facilities will be able to be aggregated with new facilities for the threshold test. In addition, the existing law does not allow for the aggregation of leased and purchased interests to be combined in assessing eligibility for the allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Sowada. Could you formally move that motion?
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That at the end of the motion, add ",but the Senate condemns the Government for the monumental failure of the Development Allowance to attract major investment, a failure which has been conclusively demonstrated by the need to amend this legislation within only 4 months of having first established the Allowance.".

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted by the adjournment motion, I was saying that the existing law does not allow for the aggregation of leased and purchased interests to be combined in assessing eligibility for the allowance. This Bill will in fact rectify that anomaly.

PARA.TAB: There are various other technical amendments effected by the legislation. I will only comment on one of these—that is, the extension of the definition of Australia to include all offshore waters. The effect of this change is to deliberately extend the development allowance to certain offshore oil and gas projects. Whilst not opposing this change, I feel it is useful to examine the recent record of the Government in extending assistance to fossil fuel industries. We saw the abolition of the coal export duty from 1 July 1992 at a cost of $47m per year. In 1990 we saw a significant relaxation of the petroleum rent resource tax at the cost of hundreds of millions of dollars over the next five years.

We have had numerous amendments to income tax legislation in terms of the timing of the deductibility of resource rent tax payments and the allowance of offshore platform removal expenses as a deduction. Yet at the same time, we have seen the pathetic dribble of a couple of million dollars a year in funding renewable energy research and development. This from a government which claims to be pursuing sustainable development.

In our Getting to Work policy statement, the Australian Democrats state that the development allowance of 10 per cent should be broadened into an ecologically sustainable development allowance. All firms, regardless of size, would be entitled to an ESD allowance in respect of investments which qualify for immediate deduction as pollution abatement or renewable energy efficiency conversions. We have also set out a variety of taxation measures to encourage ecologically sustainable practices in industry, such as restructuring the sales tax on motor vehicles to favour fuel efficient vehicles and to penalise non-efficient vehicles.

The Australian Democrats is the only party which supports reasonable encouragement of this industry into the twenty-first century. As detailed in Getting to Work, we must encourage the shift from fossil fuels to low carbon fuels and renewable energy. We have to seriously address energy efficiency, primarily at the design stage in products and buildings. Such an approach is also integral to fulfilling the Toronto targets of stabilising greenhouse gas emissions. What we need is recognition of the leading edge work of our academics. This is no longer theory; it is technical reality. Professors David Mills, Martin Green and Stephen Kaneff would be highly honoured in Japan. In Australia they are almost totally unknown and have to scrimp to obtain any kind of funding.

During the 1980s, the funding for renewable energy fell by more than 80 per cent in real terms at a time when great technical progress was made and by a government which claimed it was the greenest in the world. We need to foster this expertise with financing to start building commercial scale plants and to create markets for the private sector to thrive on.

The tax changes needed to foster this industry are immediate tax deductibility for renewable energy systems installed by business, whether in new buildings or retro-fitting existing structures, accelerated depreciation rates for energy efficient buildings, elimination of sales tax on all items which conserve energy or generate renewable energy, a reinstatement of the taxation rebate which used to exist for the cost of domestic insulation and a system of financing renewable energy technologies for widespread use—for example, to enable households to install solar hot water systems and pay off the capital cost by diverting the savings in energy costs. Private industry will not do it, so the public sector will have to.

Even the US Congress is preparing a landmark energy Bill which contemplates that about 50 per cent of the US's total energy will come from renewable sources by the year 2030. Japan has also started seriously pursuing this area so unless we commercialise our expertise fast, we will be left behind. We will also steadily lose our energy export markets as the world switches to renewables.

This is what sustainable development means. This is what the clever country means. It is about time the old parties stopped ignoring this emerging technology and started supporting Australian ingenuity and creating Australian jobs. The Australian Democrats support the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill for the same reason that we supported the original legislation. We believe that the potential benefits to Australia's high technology export industries are too great to be put at risk by petty political point scoring.

In the view of the Australian Democrats, industry is fighting backwards in one lost nation. The level playing field is really a vertical cliff over which industry is falling into an abyss of bankruptcy, rising imports and increased regulation. We do not support the level playing field. For industry to prosper we need pro-active measures on behalf of the Government to encourage investment in manufacturing, plant and equipment and to encourage Australians to throw off the enveloping cloak of recession depression and start actively promoting business investment to foster economic growth.

When the development allowance was first legislated, the Australian Democrats requested the opportunity to reassess it in 18 months' time and make any necessary amendments to improve it. The Government itself has needed to do this just four months after the principal Act was brought before us. I would agree with Senator Watson that the existing terms of the development allowance are far too restrictive and, as I said earlier, it would not surprise me if we are once again faced with having to make amendments to this legislation to provide a climate in which investment can take place in this country. We do however support the notion of sectoral assistance and suggest that this particular measure could be broadened to make it more accessible to a whole range of Australian industries that are currently excluded from the legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its cooperation in facilitating the passage of the Development Allowance Authority Bill this evening. I thank all senators, particularly Senator Watson and Senator Sowada, for somewhat shortening their contributions to make it possible for us more readily to deal with this legislation. I hope they will therefore forgive me if in reciprocating I do not respond specifically to the points they raised in the way I usually would because we all want to get the legislation passed quickly and not abuse the cooperation.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with the response to the amendment in some detail, but first I think some matters that are of some importance for those seeking to interpret the legislation need to be put on the record. The Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 provides an income tax deduction in addition to depreciation of 10 per cent of the amount of capital expenditure incurred by taxpayers on the acquisition or lease of new units of plant and equipment to be used in Australia within projects of $50m or more which meet certain criteria. The allowance applies in the year in which the particular plant is first used or held ready for use.

The allowance is targeted towards the stimulation of investment in large projects which can satisfy the DAA that they are world competitive and that the environment within which they operate is also competitive. Projects which are heavily assisted are excluded from eligibility. Each applicant must satisfy the DAA that the project does not have a nominal or effective rate of assistance, taking the lower, exceeding 10 per cent. These measures of assistance are to be calculated separately for each project taking into account all assistance received by the particular project from all levels of government in a manner consistent with the methodology used by the Industry Commission to calculate assistance.

There are a number of key dates in the legislation, the most immediately pressing of which is 1 January 1993, before which all applications must have been received by the DAA if they are to be considered. Obviously the primary purpose of this Bill is to amend the principal Act to increase the flexibility of the legislation so that a more consistent approach is available to the various types of prospective applicant for the development allowance. These amendments provide that additional flexibility for claiming the benefit, in particular in passing the $50m threshold. The opportunity is also taken to make minor adjustments to the drafting of certain provisions in the principal Act to facilitate interpretation by applicants for the allowance and to make some minor administrative adjustments.

I think I can construct everything else I want to say as a response to the second reading amendment that was moved by Senator Sowada. It is important to say that, notwithstanding that no application has been approved so far, the development allowance is a long way from having been a failure. Over 200 persons have approached the Development Allowance Authority secretariat seeking information and application forms. A number of these people are consultants, professional firms or very large companies which are working on more than one project. There are a large number of projects under consideration for application for this allowance.

The Authority has received a number of applications—a number of applications are currently before the Development Allowance Authority—and other draft applications. These are being processed at this moment. Most interest has been expressed by the mining industry and the minerals processing industry—two areas where most Australians would agree that new investment would be of great benefit to the Australian economy—because of the investment itself and the jobs and exports which may well be generated. A large proportion of companies that are expressing interest are proposing export oriented projects, which is what we hope would be the case, and offering some cause for optimism.

The purpose of the amendment is not to remedy a failure of the allowance, because there are a number of applications being processed under the Act as it stands, but, as I said, to increase the flexibility of the legislation. The development allowance was an important One Nation initiative. The Development Allowance Authority and the legislation which underpins it will have a very important role to play in enhancing the speed and the nature of the recovery. As this recovery is developed and enhanced, its nature and rate of development will be significantly enhanced by the projects which are approved and received. They will be either initiated when they otherwise might not have been or, at the very least, brought forward so that they may be undertaken more quickly. That is exactly what Australia needs at this stage of the economic cycle.

In the normal course of speaking on such a Bill—even though it is not an important Bill; it is a Bill about an important matter—I would have addressed in more detail some of the questions that were raised. With those remarks, I thank the Senate for its cooperation and facilitation of this legislation and commend it to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the debate very carefully, especially the speech by my colleague from the Australian Democrats, Senator Sowada, and the information recently provided by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan—particularly his comments that, to date, there have been 200 application inquiries. Therefore, it may be a little too early to judge whether already at this time the development allowance has been a monumental failure in attracting major investment. We believe this to be the case because of the inflexibility not only in the original proposals but also in the limited nature of these investments.

PARA.TAB: Although we are distressed at the rolling nature of government amendments to legislation, it is true that only four months have elapsed since the Government first established this development allowance. Perhaps we should give it the benefit of the doubt that at least it has taken notice of some of the remarks made in this chamber by both ourselves and the Democrats in trying to get this legislation right; perhaps I will be charitable. It is late in the night. For that reason, it is reasonable that the Liberal-National coalition will not support the content of the amendment that is proposed by the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to pay tribute to a great public servant. I am referring to the just retired Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, Mr Richard Beetham. As a consequence, it would be remiss if this Senate did not recognise Richard Beetham's retirement as a commissioner. Mr Beetham's resignation was announced in the press last Friday after the ISC confirmed this move last Thursday night.

PARA.TAB: Mr Beetham had just completed his five-year appointment on 30 September. During those five years he headed a commission which had been inadequately resourced and yet managed, through unstinting dedication from both himself and his staff, to cope with the vast overload of work presented. For this he deserves the full respect of this chamber and the superannuation and insurance industry.

To state that this man's resignation has come as a surprise to both myself and the superannuation and insurance industry would be an understatement and is indicative of the respect of the work done by the Commission under his leadership. I am disappointed to see him not continue his career within the Public Service. I note that when the Australian Financial Review contacted various insurance industry executives they all praised Mr Beetham's work and stated that there were few people within the ISC who were, or who were likely to be, successors.

Richard Beetham was the inaugural commissioner of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, appointed in 1987 when the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, combined into one organisation the supervisory policy advising and industry liaison responsibilities within the Government in regard to the life insurance, general insurance and occupational superannuation industries.

Consequently, here we have a man who had the responsibility for the establishment and development of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Over the years this body has had the supreme supervision of all life insurance, superannuation and general insurance industries and provision of policy advice on all matters relating to these industries. He came to the ISC fully qualified, having been the First Assistant Secretary of the Financial Institutions Division, Federal Treasury, for the eight previous years. In this position he was involved in giving policy advice and administration relating to most aspects of the structure and operations of the Australian financial system, including banking, other financial institutions, companies and securities markets, export finance, foreign exchange, insurance and superannuation.

Further, during those eight years as First Assistant Secretary he served on numerous committees, either as chairman or as a member, which all served to qualify him further for his role as commissioner of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. In particular, I note that he was the chairman of the Commonwealth committee on retirement incomes and chairman of the Commonwealth task force on occupational superannuation.

Richard Beetham's career has been one of the public servant. He emigrated to Australia early in his career in 1962 to avail himself of the Reserve Bank of Australia scholarship at the University of Adelaide where he researched and published his thesis on the development of non-bank financial institutions in Australia and implications for monetary theory and policy. From here he served for several years at the Reserve Bank as an economist and from thence into the Federal Treasury in both the Banking and Insurance Branch and the already mentioned Financial Institutions Division.

Mr Beetham's career with the Treasury was further extended during the three years he served at the Embassy of Australia in Washington, DC, and at the Australian High Commission, Ottawa, Canada. In Washington he was the Treasurer's senior representative. Whilst in these two posts he was involved in monitoring the economic and financial developments of both the US and Canada. He also represented Australia at the UN and liaised with private sector executives on economic and financial matters pertaining to Australia and North America.

Richard Beetham has been in charge of the ISC at a time of unprecedented change, both to policy and in the spread of superannuation, all against a backdrop of financial deregulation and turmoil. Indeed, it was the speed of Richard Beetham that prevented further chaos and loss in the ill-fated Occidental and Regal Insurance scam. The ISC stands on the verge of a massive strengthening of its supervisory powers and as the superannuation industry enters a new phase of growth in the wake of a superannuation guarantee charge.

Richard Beetham's swan song will be the soon to be released prudential statement. I understand this is due out in a few days, or perhaps later this month. This prudential statement will provide a new framework for the superannuation industry with a considerable increase in ISC responsibilities and tight new regulations governing the activities of superannuation funds. I do not think that he would take it amiss if I were to say that he has performed his onerous tasks in the best traditions of the Public Service—that is, in a low-key, meticulous, cooperative and extremely competent manner. He has sought practical and sensible solutions to a mass of new problems in an area of intense policy debate and human interest and has resisted the temptation to engage in political debate.

Whatever dissatisfaction we on this side may feel about the unrealistic pace and discretion of policy in superannuation, it does not extend to Richard Beetham, who has performed his duties admirably. I shall miss seeing him at the ISC section of the Estimates and at various superannuation and insurance inquiries at which I have had the pleasure of hearing him speak.

I understand that the resignation has come about for personal reasons. At 56, Richard Beetham is still young enough to be able to pursue his other interests. I have been informed that he may even consider another full time position. Personally, I believe that his qualifications would make him an excellent director or member of a company board. Indeed, I would like to take this opportunity of saying that I had always envisaged Richard Beetham on the Reserve Bank Board because of his outstanding financial and economic qualifications.

I note that today the Federal Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has announced the new ISC Commissioner as Mr George Pooley. Mr Pooley is another senior Treasury official and former member of the Foreign Investment Review Board. I have been told that Mr Pooley occupied Richard Beetham's old position in Treasury. It is indeed a mark of the ability of the ex-Commissioner that the Government has deliberately looked to another man with the same background.

I congratulate Mr Pooley on his appointment and look forward to having the same relationship that existed between myself and other members of this chamber with the ex-Commissioner. More importantly at this time I wish the retiring Commissioner, Mr Richard Beetham, well in whatever he decides to do next.

SPEECH.PARA: In Mary Salter's letter, she remarks on the similarity of the problems of the Indian people to those of Aboriginal people in Australia. The comparison is appropriate. I therefore remind the Senate of the importance of 1993 being the Year for the World's Indigenous People. While it does not officially commence until 10 December 1992, it is certainly not too early to raise the issue in the Senate, especially on this day, and to consider how this year can provide a landmark in the place of indigenous people in today's world.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate of the national objectives of the Year for the World's Indigenous People so that we can seek to fulfil them in the year ahead. They are, first, to enhance relations between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and the broader community; secondly, to increase the knowledge and understanding in the domestic and international community about the world's indigenous peoples, in particular, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples; thirdly, to identify activities through policy and program development to improve the socio-cultural position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples; and, finally, to maximise the involvement of non-government organisations, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and community-based individuals in the achievement of the national objectives.

I seek to incorporate in Hansard some words of Burnum Burnum, a man who, in his own words, had to search `to get closer to my own Aboriginality'. The words come from an extract from the foreword of Burnum Burnum's book A Traveller's Guide to Aboriginal Australia. They present an authentic and authoritative account while seeking to extend the hand of friendship to guide us all into a respectful and enriching future together. It is a short extract, but to save the time of the Senate I seek leave to incorporate it into Hansard.
Leave granted.
The extract read as follows—

This book is the expression of that mission, an attempt to give the traveller a chance to view this extraordinary country as it was seen by the original Australians. On the journey we get a glimpse of the Dreamtime through the oral traditions of many of the nations which made up this great country. The work of archaeologists is also illuminating, as they scrape through layers of history in their own search for the roots of perhaps the most successful people who ever lived on this planet. Modern ecology can learn a great deal from a people who managed and maintained their world so well for 50 000 years.

As we move through the landscape and the traditional lands of the nations who once ruled this continent, we see how they lived, the foods they ate and the traditions which kept their culture alive for so long. Much of this lives on today and Australians are gaining a new pride in their real heritage, the one which covers 2000 generations.

The story has an inevitable edge of sadness, as we understand the process and pattern of dispossession suffered after 1788. This material has been included not to provoke guilt, but to give a perception of the extraordinary differences between the original Australians and the invaders who came in 1788. In most areas of early contact, they were greeted warmly by the Australians, who had no idea that these strange white people intended to stay. The land had been under their control and guidance going back to the Dreamtime; every hill, valley, river, animal and plant had been placed in the landscape for the use of the people. The thought of somebody arriving from the edge of the ocean to simply take their lands was inconceivable and the reality of their new position was slow to dawn. When it did, resistance grew and we will look at the efforts of several individuals who stood courageously against the invasion of firepower of the Europeans.

We also see the ongoing struggle for land rights, as attempts are made to redress the imbalance of dispossession created by the doctrine of terra nullius, which meant, literally, that there were no people on the continent. Non-Aboriginal people often find it difficult to understand the traditional relationship between the land and its people. The concept of land ownership, in the western model, was simply beyond the comprehension of the original Australians.

In Europe, as people developed their civilisation from the caves to the cathedrals, they left clear evidence of their achievement for future generations to admire. In Australia, the land itself is the cathedral and worship is not confined to any four walls. Each step is a prayer and every form in the landscape—and every thing that moves in it—were put there specifically for the people to use and manage. And the mythic beings made clear the responsibility of the people in preserving and nurturing the environment. Their success in managing their world so successfully, and sustaining their culture for so long, is now attracting the world-wide respect it deserves.

I hope the reader will find no bitterness in the story: the past cannot be turned back. The story of dispossession is a sand and moving one, but many of the Dreamtime stories are equally tragic. The challenge of the future is the important issue, and an acceptance of the past is the first step to a positive future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to an anomaly that I hope can be rectified in relation to the issuing of passports. The problem relates to people who were born in the United Kingdom, many of whom served in the Second World War but who had migrated to Australia prior to the commencement of the Second World War. They are now being asked when they renew their passports to produce documents of citizenship, which they were not originally required to do when they were granted Australian citizenship in the 1950s, and at a very high cost.

PARA.TAB: These people are now quite advanced in years. The correspondent who has raised the issue with me is 76 and, as he says, is `still going'. It is an enormous difficulty. If I might highlight the problem that my constituent has raised, I think it will shed light on the general issue. My constituent, a Mr Thompson, migrated to Australia in 1936. At the outbreak of the Second World War he joined the 2nd AIF. At the end of the Second World War, he was demobbed and returned to Australia, and in 1949 he became an Australian citizen by virtue of an Act of Parliament. In 1950, he applied for and was granted an Australian passport which stated inside the cover that he was an Australian subject in accordance with the Nationality Act.

In 1989, Mr Thompson sought to renew his then expired passport and was told that he could not do so unless he provided documents of citizenship, which were going to cost him a not insubstantial sum of money. He refused to do so on principle, the principle being that he already had an Australian passport and was now being put to extra expense notwithstanding the fact that by an Act of Parliament he had been granted Australian citizenship.

In the intervening period, he does not seem to have had any luck in getting this matter properly addressed. As he quite neatly points out, when he came back from the Second World War and returned to Australia, having been demobbed, he was not asked to pay $50 for a visa. Because of the rush to get overseas in 1989, he had to get a British passport but was required to pay $50 on top of the cost of the British passport to get his visa to come back into the country, notwithstanding the fact that he has dual citizenship. He had to get the visa of course because he did not have an Australian passport.

No doubt many people are in Mr Thompson's position. Something needs to be done to rectify this position. These men and women are veterans who have served this country very well. They are Australian citizens, but by a quirk of government regulation they are now required to go to additional expense should they wish to renew their passports. If these fine men and women wish to display and be proud of their Australian nationality by carrying an Australian passport, I believe it is inappropriate for the Government to make it more difficult for them to do so. I hope that somebody in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or somebody else within the Government can write to me or perhaps Mr Thompson to clarify the position and, hopefully, eliminate this absurd problem which currently exists.
