TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the names and addresses of all groups and individuals who sent submissions to the Minister, the department and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in respect of the Disability Discrimination Bill 1992.
(2) What reasons were given for the acceptance or rejection of the legislation and what were the details of any major concerns.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The release of the names and addresses of both individuals and groups who made submissions in relation to this legislation raises serious issues of privacy. I am not prepared to release such details.

(2) In relation to the second question I am prepared to give an overview of the main issues raised in the submissions of the major areas of concern. In relation to each, I also note the Government's reaction.
The overwhelming majority of responses were in favour of the Commonwealth legislating in this area and gave broad support to the Bill.
There were, however, a number of areas where some concerns were expressed.

A number of submissions indicated that a less medical definition of disability would help to preclude value judgements being made on the abilities of people with disabilities. There were also concerns that certain disabilities such as cognitive and neurological disorders were not covered.

The definition is based on existing legislation in the States and Territories. The use of the terms such as `condition' as suggested by some submissions was thought capable of including such temporary states as drunkenness or the effects of the recreational use of drugs. Whilst it is arguable that this is not the case it was thought that to use this word would have the potential to cause confusion and as result no amendment was adopted.

In relation to cognitive and neurological disorders, subclause (g) of the definition was inserted specifically to include such disabilities. The Explanatory Memorandum has been amended to include reference to these disabilities.

A number of submissions considered that not only should the evidentiary burden of proving that unjustifiable hardship be with the person asserting that he or she will suffer it but that that person should have the legal burden of proving unjustifiable hardship on the balance of probabilities.

Whilst a number of State Acts do contain such a burden this is not consistent with usual Commonwealth policy and could impose considerable burdens upon small business and industry. It is believed that the existing provision represents a satisfactory compromise.
There were a number of concerns expressed about the lack of a formal mechanism to check, monitor and review action plans.

The concept of action plans is that they be voluntary and not be forced upon service providers as another way of enforcing minimum standards. To establish an effective monitoring mechanism would involve the establishment of another agency with the attendant cost involved in that process. The incentive is there for service providers to compile such plans in that they are able to plan for a longer term solution to the problems of discriminatory practices.

There was considerable comment received in relation to the need for all parties potentially affected by such standards to be involved in an extensive consultation process if and when it is decided that such standards are necessary. Such comment has been received from those States who have responded to the legislation.

As indicated by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services in the Second Reading Speech and reinforced by the Minister's Parliamentary Secretary during the Committee stage in the House the Government is very aware of the potential effect of any standards that may be introduced. The Government is quite prepared to give an unequivocal undertaking that such consultations will be entered into both on the formulation of draft standards and on the actual draft standards prior to them being enacted in regulations.

Some submissions also asked why the standards do not cover all areas of discrimination covered by the Bill. Essentially the areas where standards are able to be made represent the areas identified as the major priority areas. The Government will monitor the operation of any standards that may be introduced and will seriously consider the need for expanding the areas covered if a need becomes apparent.
A number of submissions suggested that harassment by one student against another and by a student against a teacher, at least at tertiary level, should be made unlawful by the Bill.

The Government considers that this issue requires further consideration as it is likely to promote considerable controversy in the community. It may be that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission should be asked to look into this issue once the legislation has passed.

A number of submissions suggested that there should be a provision to make it clear that clubs which have membership or certain categories of membership restricted to people with disabilities would be able to continue to operate without interference from this Bill. The Government introduced, in the House, a suitable amendment to Clause 27 of the Bill to give effect to this suggestion.

ANSWER.PARA: Operation of State and Territory Laws.

PARA.TAB: A number of submissions suggested that the provisions of clause 13 which require a complainant to choose to proceed under either Commonwealth, State or Territory law impose an unreasonable burden on complainants.

The provisions of this clause have a dual purpose in that they protect the concurrent operation of State and Territory law with that of the Commonwealth and also guard against double jeopardy. The clause is closely based upon similar provisions in the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. These provisions have not caused difficulties in practice particularly as there are arrangements between the Commonwealth and most State and Territory governments whereby Commonwealth and State or Territory legislation is administered by a single agency in each of those States and Territories which have this form of legislation.
The Government is prepared to monitor the operation of these provisions but does not believe that there is any need to amend provisions which have operated well in other legislation.

There were a number of submissions which criticised the extent of exemptions contained in the Bill. The most concern was expressed about the exemptions relating to telecommunications carriers and migration contained in clauses 50 and 52.

In relation to telecommunications carriers, this exemption only relates to their operations as service providers not as employers and only operates for a period of three years. The provision is designed to allow time for the Government's micro-economic reforms in this area to be implemented without imposing potentially major costs which may be incurred if the Bill were to operate on the carriers from the day the legislation comes into force.

There were also agreements entered into by the Commonwealth with the second carrier that the Commonwealth would not significantly change the playing field on which the new carrier would be operating during the time that the operator was becoming established.

The most concern about this exemption came from the hearing impaired. The Government has responded to their special needs by announcing in the Budget that a pilot scheme for the possible introduction of a national telephone typewriter service would be established in Sydney and Melbourne.

In relation to Migration there already exists within the Migration Act a system of review of those decisions. The addition of a further avenue of possible review would only serve to further complicate that system. Parts of that system are presently undergoing a review to streamline the process.

A number of submissions from bodies representing certain health professionals queried whether the legislation gives them sufficient protection where there is a need to provide services in a particular manner to certain people who would come within the definition of disability. They particularly raised the issue of people who were HIV positive.

The Government considers that the legislation provides sufficient protection to health professionals. Firstly, the provisions of clause 48 provide that it is not an unlawful practice to discriminate where that discrimination relates to infectious diseases and is necessary to protect public health. Further the provision of health services would come under clause 24 of the Bill. That provision is subject to the exemption relating to unjustifiable hardship. When determining whether unjustifiable hardship exists clause 11(a) requires the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to take into account the nature of the benefit or detriment likely to be suffered by all concerned including, in this case, the health professional.
There were a number of suggestions for amendments of a procedural nature some of which the Government took up and appropriate amendments were made to the Bill in the House of Representatives.

the installation of any line, or the installation of any equipment, used or intended for use in connection with a telecommunications service or the operation or maintenance of a telecommunications system; or
the identifying or tracing of any person who has contravened or is likely to contravene a provision of Part VIIB the Crimes Act 1914.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 28 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is Telecom's Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) secure from accidental, illicit or illegal interception.

(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to cases in which subscribers using the Public Switching Traffic Network (PSTN) have inadvertently gained access to ISDN lines, and that Telecom has been unwilling or unable to provide a satisfactory explanation for these breaches of network security.

(3) Is it correct that in at least one such case, in which the ISDN subscriber was utilising Calling Line Identification facilities, the PSTN subscriber's telephone number was not the number shown on the ISDN subscriber's computer screen; if so, what explanation can Telecom provide for this breach of security between the ISDN and PSTN.

(4) Can the Minister provide assurances that consumers' privacy is being protected by Telecom in relation to the ISDN, and explain the means by which consumers' privacy will be protected by Optus when it commences service.
(5) Which Government agencies and services are using Calling Line Identification and Calling Number Display facilities, and for what purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised by AOTC that ISDN is a network which interworks with AOTC's other network based services including the Public Switched Telephone service (PSTN), MobileNet, CustomNet Spectrum and the various information services. Therefore, it is possible for voice calls to be established between any two customers connected to any of these network based services. ISDN is currently unique because it is designed to carry digital data and voice services all on the one network. However, digital data will only be carried between two parties if they are both connected to the ISDN.

The technology of ISDN is complex and it is unlikely that accidental interception would occur. Not only are the communications channels separated from the signalling channels but there is a significant level of partitioning between the paths of communication between any two customers.

Whilst the possibility of illicit or illegal interception can never be ruled out, the probability of such an incident is diminished on ISDN because of the technical complexity of the service and the cost of the required equipment. If customers require a higher degree of privacy or security it is possible for them to include encryption devices in the path of the communications circuit on their customer equipment.

(2) No, I am not aware of any specific cases of inadvertent access to ISDN lines. However, as indicated in my response to question (1), there is the potential for such connections to be established because of the interworking of networks.

(3) ISDN customers who subscribe to the calling line identification presentation (CLIP) service can receive the calling line identification (CLI) of callers who are also on the ISDN. CLIP is not, however, possible for calls from customers on the PSTN. In these cases the CLI received will be a blank.
If the honourable senator has any information of a specific incident where this was not the case, AOTC has indicated that it would be pleased to investigate the matter.

(4) A customer who is connected to ISDN has control over the forward presentation of identification information to a called party. It is a matter of choice whether the customer forwards identification information with calls.

A customer who is connected to ISDN has the capability to screen incoming calls to selectively deflect unwanted calls if the incoming call includes CLI. This capability is most useful if CLI is normally presented as part of a normal call and enhances a customer's level of privacy.

The signalling systems which are available between the carriers will provide Optus with the ability to manage the privacy of their customers in a similar manner to AOTC. I understand that Optus plans to commence its ISDN services in January 1994.

(5) Disclosure by AOTC of information on Government agencies connected to ISDN is not permitted under the Telecommunications Act 1991. The information on their subscription to CLIP is therefore also confidential.
It is important to recognise that CLIP is, in any event, a feature offered by most PABX systems.

Calling Number Display (CND) is a service which can be associated with a customer's analogue connection to the PSTN. However, it is not a service which AOTC offers at this stage. The future availability of this service and how it may be offered to customers is currently being considered by AUSTEL as part of its Privacy Inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 8 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which countries have banned the cyclodiene pesticides heptachlor and chlordane and for each pesticide, what was the reason provided for banning it.

(2) Would it be of concern to the Minister if, in spite of the fact that regulatory authorities in dozens of countries banned or severely restricted these chemicals for either health or environmental reasons, the National Health and Medical Research Council, failed to find reasons to be concerned about the continued use of these chemicals in Australia, on either health or environmental grounds.
(3) Which major reputable public and occupational health authorities outside Australia classify heptachlor and chlordane as probable or possible human carcinogens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) On the information available to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), the regulatory situation in foreign countries for the cyclodiene pesticides chlordane and heptachlor is as follows. In the USA, chlordane and heptachlor maintain conditional registration pending the receipt of air monitoring studies. To date, these studies have not been received by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and therefore these products are precluded from sale or use in the USA. In the United Kingdom, registrations for chlordane and heptachlor have been revoked due to persistence of these chemicals in the environment. In Canada most registrations for heptachlor have been withdrawn due to environmental persistence, while limited registrations of chlordane remain. These chemicals apparently continue to be used in some other countries, particularly for termite control, with varying degrees of restriction. Further details on the status of these chemicals in other countries is outlined in the draft Report of the NHMRC Working Party on Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia which was released for public comment in January 1992.

(2) The use of these chemicals in Australia has been severely restricted. Further restrictive steps were proposed in the draft report referred to in (1) above and the issue will be further considered by the NHMRC at its Council meeting in November this year.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Two agencies which classify chemicals as carcinogens in the way the Senator refers are the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The IARC has recently re-reviewed the epidemiological data and animal toxicology data on the potential carcinogenicity of chlordane and heptachlor which is published in volume 53 of its monograph series. On the basis of the epidemiological data and case reports, it was concluded that there is inadequate evidence in humans for the carcinogenicity of chlordane and of heptachlor. On the basis of the animal toxicology data, it was concluded that there is sufficient evidence in experimental animals for the carcinogenicity of chlordane and heptachlor. The overall evaluation according to the criteria of the IARC classification scheme, was that both chlordane and heptachlor are possibly carcinogenic to humans. The US EPA classify chlordane and heptachlor similarly, according to the EPA's Guidelines for Carcinogenic Risk Assessment.
